How Many Survived?.name: How Many Survived?
How Many Survived?.text:
How Many Survived?

Now that the PCs have led the Eurythnians to safety, it's time to determine how many people survived the trip. Remember that a single Survival Point roughly equates to about 100 people!

Overwhelming Success (76–100 Survival Points): Enough of the people of Xin-Eurythnia survive that they maintain their society. Talk of returning home to reclaim and rebuild is popular. They remain tightly knit and make trips to Varisian cities over the next several months to gather interest and support for an eventual return to Xin-Eurythnia. The PCs earn 120 XP and gain 3 Mythic Points each.

Tragic Success (26–75 Survival Points): While about a quarter of the survivors have lost interest and seek to resettle in Vekker's Crossing, the remainder organize into smaller groups that then travel to Varisia's major cities as detailed above, although nearly half eventually give up the mission to make new lives elsewhere. The PCs earn 80 XP and gain 2 Mythic Points each.

Near Disaster (1–25 Survival Points): The number of survivors is depressingly small. No one wants to return to Xin-Eurythnia, and two-thirds refugees just end up resettling in Vekker's Crossing. The remainder scatter, either seeking new lives to the southwest in Varisia or leading desperate small groups back north to try to track down and rescue anyone who might still be lost. Most of those who go on these rescue missions are never seen again. The PCs earn 40 XP and gain 1 Mythic Point each.

Total Failure (0 Survival Points): The PCs and a handful of [[/r 2d20]] refugees are all that's left. The survivors integrate wholly into the population of Vekker's Crossing. The legacy of Xin-Eurythnia will be lost unless the PCs can stop Xanderghul, and even then, Sorshen (or whoever inherits rule of the city) will have to start from the beginning to build the city all over again. The PCs earn no XP or Mythic Points.

Flight of the Eurythnians.name: Flight of the Eurythnians
Flight of the Eurythnians.text:
Chapter 2: Flight of the Eurythnians

With Sorshen missing and the city in chaos, there's no time to dawdle. Disasters continue to plague the city as aftershocks and landslides strike every few hours, while at the same time, all manner of monsters who've long lurked in the dark, hidden corners of the ancient runelord capital rouse and clamber into the streets above. At the same time, the city's populace show their true colors, be it rising to the challenge to organize defenses and protect their neighbors or taking advantage of the devastation and mayhem to loot and plunder.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.RN0Zhxpmp9tFJqhO.PlaylistSound.vcRZekYV73pjtsTS]{Devastated Xin Eurythnia}

As the PCs recover from their fight against the erons of Jandelay, give them time to heal up and regroup. During this time, the landslide and release of magical energy from the collapse of Karzoug's visage at the top of Mhar Massif and the destruction of the Pinnacle of Avarice comes to a slow halt—Xin-Eurythnia is two miles away from the event, but the debris field of the collapse makes it halfway to the city's northern edge before coming to a halt.

Supernatural Stalkers.name: Supernatural Stalkers
Supernatural Stalkers.text:
Supernatural Stalkers

Survival Points

When this adventure begins, Xin-Eurythnia has a population of 12,500 citizens. In the immediate aftermath at the end of @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21901theris]{Chapter 1}, many powerful spellcasters abandon the city. Those who attempt to do so via teleportation quickly learn of the region's dimensional damage, but others cast spells like umbral journey to flee with as many close friends and family as they can take. Still, thousands of citizen remain who are chased down by monsters, trapped under debris, or otherwise in peril. These endangered citizens are represented by a total number of “Survival Points.” Each point roughly represents 100 people.

At the start of this chapter, the Eurythnians have 100 Survival Points (with the extra 25 potential points representing those who escaped or perished). As the PCs meet with failure for the rest of the chapter, these points will be reduced; the final number of Survival Points remaining at the end of the chapter determines how successful the evacuation effort ultimately was.

Throughout the chapter, the PCs have two unusual recurrences that only they experience. The first is constant glimpses of immense, one-eyed, spider-like creatures watching them from perches atop the surrounding mountaintops. These distant figures are the Watchers of Jandelay, omens of the apocalypse keeping an eye on the situation to see how it unfolds. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[occultism|dc:44] check recognizes these creatures for what they are, and understands their presence is not quite physical, yet remains an ominous portent of imminent cataclysms.

While the presence of these watchers lessens when the PCs lead the civilians out of the city, their second experience haunts them throughout the chapter: nightmares of an apocalypse. Each time the party rests, the PCs all share similarly themed (but distinctly individual) nightmares of impending apocalypses. These nightmares are the result of misery siktemporas sent to this world by the Ashen Man to torment the PCs by casting nightmare on them nightly, and once these creatures are finally encountered and defeated during @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21902flight.JournalEntryPage.02event7nightm00]{Event 7}, the recurring nightmares end.

Immediate Perils.name: Immediate Perils
Immediate Perils.text:
Immediate Perils

The ancient wonder of Xin-Eurythnia has taken its greatest hit since Earthfall. When the PCs are about to leave the plaza, Ayavah staggers out to approach them. She's shaken and covered with dust, but waves aside her own safety as she begs the PCs to help her gather civilians to prepare for an evacuation. Ayavah urges the PCs to act quickly, as she fears these events are but a prelude to an even greater disaster—the eruption of Mhar Massif itself!

Supply Points

When the PCs begin the process of leading the Eurythnians south to safety, they'll start with a set number of Supply Points representing food, water, shelter, tools, and other supplies that are necessary to keep the refugees alive on the journey. Rules for Supply Points appear @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21902flight.JournalEntryPage.02evacuationpr00]{Here}, but during this chapter's first portion, certain success the PCs achieve earn them additional Supply Points. Keep track of these extra points, and when the evacuation begins, increase the Eurythnians' starting Supply Points by this amount.

Ayavah reiterates her fear that things are dire in the city, and that an evacuation of its citizens is paramount. She notes that Midnight's Gallery still stands, thanking the Redeemer Queen for this mercy, and informs the PCs that the cathedral can serve as an initial staging ground for the gathering of refugees, but before the task of evacuating the city can even begin, there are immediate perils that must be taken care of, and asks the PCs to do what they can to address the following crises.

Word of these unfolding disasters is on everyone's lips. This encounter uses the beat the clock version of the chase rules (GM Core 192), with the PCs racing to overcome the five obstacles before lives are lost. When the encounter begins, present the five obstacles to the players, then on each round, the PCs can attempt to accumulate “Rescue Points” for each obstacle in order to overcome them. The PCs can attempt these checks in any order they wish, and need not all work together to do so, but the group does have only 5 ten-minute rounds to overcome as many of the obstacles as they can.

Distorted Gravity Obstacle

Rescue Points 3

Overcome @Check[acrobatics|dc:33] to navigate the unusual gravity and thus determine the safest routes out or @Check[nature|dc:36] to seize the distorted primal magic in the area and temporarily repair it.

Aftershocks have wreaked havoc on the laws of the Universe in this neighborhood, distorting gravity so that some carts and people are in danger of floating away while others are pinned to the ground by the weight of gravity.

Gaping Chasm Obstacle

Rescue Points 2

Overcome @Check[athletics|dc:33] to clamber down and rescue those who have fallen, @Check[crafting|dc:36] to come up with an astounding jury-rigged solution to brace collapsing buildings long enough to effect rescues.

A vast rift has opened in the streets, and dozens of helpless citizens are in danger of falling in as buildings slowly crumble into the chasm.

Monster Uprising Obstacle

Rescue Points 3

Overcome weapon or spell Strike against AC 33 to fight back against the monsters or @Check[intimidation|dc:36] to frighten the monsters into retreating back underground.

A building has partially collapsed into a sinkhole that opened into a set of caverns below, allowing the hungry oozes, prowling fungi, and Darklands monsters dwelling within to creep out and hunt for fresh prey among the frightened locals.

Risen Cultists Obstacle

Rescue Points 3

Overcome @Check[stealth|dc:33] to help sneak the locals in the area out to safety or @Check[religion|dc:36] to disrupt the cultists' rhetoric and magic with prayers of your own.

In the aftermath of the event, additional cells of Risen cultists emerge from the city's shadows and attempt to subjugate the populace. Without risen Runelord Gimmel's leadership, these attacks are disorganized, but one group of lamia cultists in the area are particularly dangerous.

Sudden Freeze Obstacle

Rescue Points 2

Overcome @Check[survival|dc:33] to provide protective aid from the elements or @Check[arcana|dc:36] to bolster the failing protection in the area.

The city's magical protection against the climate has been severely damaged by destruction, but in this neighborhood it has nearly completely failed, threatening lives through freezing and altitude sickness

Reward: Handling these perils is a mythic deed—if the PCs overcome all five obstacles, restore 3 Mythic Points to each PC. In addition, for each obstacle the PCs overcome, grant them 40 XP and 200 XP if they complete them all.

Any obstacle the PCs fail to overcome by the time their five rounds are up reduces their starting Survival Points by 1 per incomplete obstacle, as many of those in the area perish—see the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21902flight.JournalEntryPage.02supernatural00#survival-points]{Survival Points} sidebar above for more details.

Urban Survival.name: Urban Survival
Urban Survival.text:
Urban Survival

The next few days after what becomes known as Doom's Night are chaotic and frantic, as survivors gather together in shelters throughout the city. As the days go on and landslides, trembling aftershocks, and continual incursions from the monster-haunted catacombs and caverns below persist, all in the shadow of Queen Sorshen's continuing absence, more and more people begin to consider fleeing the city entirely. Yet for most of Xin-Edasseril's populace, such a journey through the mountains would be deadly. Before any such evacuation can start, new leaders need to take up the vacuum left by the vanished Sorshen. While many NPCs in Xin-Edasseril initially vie for the role, most of them have their own agendas, and none can get their act together fast enough. The role of leading the refugees from Xin-Eurythnia falls to the PCs.

Ayavah quickly warms to the idea of their leadership. Any PC who considers the logistics of the evacuation and succeeds at a @Check[society|dc:25] check notes that there is really only one safe, realistic route to safety—south through the Kodar Mountains to the smaller city of Vekker's Crossing. If no PC comes up with this idea, Ayavah suggests it.

After the PCs help with the Immediate Perils, things in the city stabilize somewhat, although it should be apparent that the situation is still degrading. Primary among the fears are the failing magic wards that keep Xin-Eurythnia comfortable and habitable. While a new earthquake or volcanic eruption might feel like they could occur at any moment, the failing wards will collapse entirely in about a week, as Ayavah or a PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:25|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge can confirm after studying the failing magic for an hour.

During this week, the PCs must do their best to prepare for a mass exodus of the city, gain the cooperation of several of the city's influential citizens, and handle any unexpected complications that arise. These play out in a combination of Downtime activities and diplomatic missions. Provide the players with a full list of these activities and missions so they can choose each day what they wish to pursue.

Each day, the PCs can pursue one of the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21902flight.JournalEntryPage.02evacuationpr00]{Evacuation Preparation} downtime activities. If they undertake a @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21902flight.JournalEntryPage.02diplomaticmi00]{Diplomatic Mission} during that same day, they can still each pursue an Evacuation Preparation, but since they have to rush that activity (due to time spent on the mission), raise all DCs associated with that activity by 5.

Dimensional Damage.name: Dimensional Damage
Dimensional Damage.text:
Dimensional Damage

If the PCs haven't realized it already, Ayavah reveals what she's learned from other scholars about the dimensional damage done to the region. Whether as the primary cause of the events of Doom's Night or merely a side effect, teleportation magic in the region has grown dangerous. All signs point to this being a temporary effect, but one that will outlast the number of days the Eurythnians have left before the city's wards fail. Short-range teleportation seems to work fine, but longer distances are now dangerous.

For the remainder of this chapter, whenever a character creates a teleportation effect that attempts to cover more than a mile in distance or attempts to travel to another plane, it automatically fails. Attempt a @Check[type:flat|dc:13]. On a success, the resource used to make the attempt is not lost. On a critical failure, not only is the resource lost, but harrowing dimensional warping affects the caster, causing them to become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}.

Diplomatic Missions.name: Diplomatic Missions
Diplomatic Missions.text:
Diplomatic Missions

In order for an evacuation of a city the size of Xin-Eurythnia to go well, the PCs need more than just to be viewed as leaders—they need the support of movers and shakers in the city. With Ayavah's friendship, they already have the support of the city's artists and those of a more faithful bent, but three other significant factions exist—the city's wizards (now that Sorshen is gone), the city's merchants, and the city's giants (who represent the guards and architects).

The leaders of these three factions are eager to met with the PCs. While they know an evacuation is required, they aren't yet sure these newcomers are the ones to lead the refugees out. The leaders meet with the PCs at the Cathedral of @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21904noctic]{Nocticula} when they're ready, during which the PCs must do their best to secure their cooperation with the following influence encounter ( GM Core 187).

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.RN0Zhxpmp9tFJqhO.PlaylistSound.re6oP2DNCoCc20Yy]{Midnight's Gallery}

During this encounter, the PCs have 4 30-minute rounds to gain influence with the NPCs before they form their final opinions. The three leaders include Vokshar Verglask (stern frost giant architect 13), Sonrasi (calculating lamia matriarch merchant 13), and Jatheriel Five-Runes (enthusiastic male elf wizard 13). Despite their different personalities, only a single influence encounter is needed to impress them all.

Faction Leaders Level 13

  • Rare

Influential local leaders

Perception +23

Will +23

Discovery @Check[academia-lore|dc:29|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover] (Jatheriel), @Check[architecture-lore|dc:29|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover] (Vokshar), or @Check[mercantile-lore|dc:29|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover] (Sonrasi); @Check[society|dc:31|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover], @Check[perception|dc:33|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover]

Influence Skills @Check[arcana|dc:31|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (Jatheriel), @Check[crafting|dc:31|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (Vokshar), @Check[thievery|dc:31|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (Sonrasi), @Check[diplomacy|dc:33|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence], @Check[deception|dc:34|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence], @Check[intimidation|dc:36|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence]

Influence 3 The faction leaders agree to donate many of their group's resources and supplies to the evacuation; the PCs earn 1 Protection Point.

Influence 6 The faction leaders agree to formally take a leadership role among the evacuees, while also fully supporting the PCs. Each grants the party an extra gift as a show of their support. The PCs earn 2 Protection Points.

Resistances The faction leaders are proud and demand respect. A PC who insults them or questions their loyalty to Xin-Eurythnia causes all Influence DCs for that faction leader to increase by 2.

Weaknesses The faction leaders are proud of their accomplishments. Complimenting their contributions to Xin-Eurythnia during an Influence check grants the PC a +1 circumstance bonus.

Background see above

Appearance Jatheriel (a reedy elf in immaculately fitted robes who always looks like he needs four more hours of sleep); Sonrasi (a middle-aged human wearing sleek but outdated makeup and perfectly coiffed hair); Vokshar (a muscular frost giant whose clothing is decorated with imagery of his ancestors)

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.f4GbKRKIlqM1FmGF]{Faction Leaders' Reward}
If the PCs reach 6 Influence Points before time is up, Jatheriel gives the PCs a wand of wall of force , Vokshar, a +2 striking shockwave warhammer , and Sonrasi, an eye of fortune .

Reward: Grant the PCs 40 XP for each Protection Point they earn in this encounter.

Event 6: Mhar Massif Stirs.name: Event 6: Mhar Massif Stirs
Event 6: Mhar Massif Stirs.text:
Event 6: Mhar Massif Stirs Moderate 13

This event takes place on the evening of the 7th day (or if the PCs decide to lead the expedition out of Xin-Eurythnia sooner than that, just as they're preparing to head out). Ayavah asks the PCs to meet her out in front of Midnight's Gallery that evening, where she thanks the PCs for all the support they've given the city. She locks up the front entrance to the cathedral, utters a short prayer to promise they'll return as soon as they can, and then turns back to the PCs and seems about to say something when suddenly, another tremor strikes the city.

Unlike the other small aftershocks, though, this one grows. As the ground shakes, the PCs stumble and stagger (feel free to ask for @Check[reflex|dc:25] saves to avoid falling @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}), and then the jagged scar at the peak of Mhar Massif that, until a week ago, held Karzoug's face explodes. A blast of thick, dark smoke belches out of the immense volcano's peak, and a few rounds later the sound of the eruption rolls over the city. Fortunately, this eruption tapers off before it fully blows the top off the towering volcano, but something strange suddenly emerges from the ashes of the eruption itself—several thin glowing streaks of what at first appears to be lava hurled through the air. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:31] check confirms that they're a dozen immense, centipede-like monstrosities, glowing red hot as they're blasted out of the mountain's peak!

Creature: This isn't a full-scale eruption but remains a harrowing reminder of the borrowed time the PCs and Eurythnians are living on the longer they remain in the area. Unknown to many, Mhar Massif is no ordinary volcano. Deep within slumbers an eldritch entity, the Great Old One known as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.FHZ2DZEJzjrPfyjH]{Mhar}, who has long slumbered beneath the earth. The events of Doom's Night have caused Mhar to stir in his slumber, and the creatures that have emerged are pyroclastic mukradis. While most of these mythic monsters have been hurled in other directions into the surrounding mountains (and may, over the course of time, cause additional troubles of their own), one of them makes a unmistakable beeline directly for Xin-Eurythnia, drawn to the very spot where Doom's Night began.

Event 6: Mhar Massif Stirs Moderate 13

@UUID[Actor.ofmiIfEwqQkpcfCG]{Pyroclastic Mukradi}

The PCs have only 2 rounds to prepare before this pyroclastic mukradi lands in the middle of Temple Plaza. The creature takes no damage from its landing as it skids into the center of the square and comes to a stop near the sinkhole, roaring in fury. The PCs are only a few hundred feet away to the east, and if they don't rush to attack this new threat, Ayavah begs them to defeat it before it devastates more of the city or, even worse, finds the gathered refugees.

Even if the PCs hold back, the pyroclastic mukradi swiftly senses the mythic power in each of the PCs and is drawn to them like the proverbial moth to a flame. The monster fights to the death. When it's slain, it gives a rattling death howl and then crumbles into ash—at the same moment, the eruption of Mhar Massif comes to a welcome end, although the looming ash cloud remains a stark reminder in the sky behind the PCs for days to come.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.mTcmrFiQ7XNalKLZ]{Ashes} @UUID[Actor.FeDUOgTsGGjY5S6X]{Avayah's Gift}
Upon defeat, something orange glows and flickers among the pyroclastic mukradi's ashes. A PC who investigates further finds several glowing shards of lava—seven frozen lava of Mhar Massif. Soon after, Ayavah approaches the PCs and congratulates them on their victory, then reveals what she was about to say just before the eruption—that she wanted to give the party her temple's greatest treasure, a +2 greater striking spell reservoir dagger containing an enfeeble spell, to aid them in their adventures to come.

Journeying South.name: Journeying South
Journeying South.text:
Journeying South

One week after Doom's Night, and likely the morning after Mhar Massif stirs, the people of Xin-Eurythnia are largely ready to flee to safer lands to the south. This is a dangerous journey to make without more preparation, made worse by the scale of the undertaking and because the refugees are frightened, saddened, and angry at having to leave their homes. It's a small blessing that few of the Eurythnians lived in the city long enough to put down roots, but to be forced to abandon a new and welcoming home is demoralizing.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.RN0Zhxpmp9tFJqhO.PlaylistSound.nbc41GORYCpSoFMz]{Journey} @UUID[Playlist.RN0Zhxpmp9tFJqhO.PlaylistSound.lsTTMSdU7YBep99c]{Campsite} @UUID[Playlist.RN0Zhxpmp9tFJqhO.PlaylistSound.I0pJ9fMVA6cpVYAm]{Nature}

The endpoint of this evacuation is 100 miles to the south along a series of mountain passes and valleys that run roughly along the west bank of the River Avah down to the point in the foothills where this river empties into the larger Kazaron. Here, a relatively new trading town called Vekker's Crossing has sprung up in the past decade, a place that's regarded as the “last stop in civilization” on the journey north to Xin-Eurythnia.

Due to the size and complexity of the evacuation, the Eurythnians can cover 10 miles per day. At this pace, it'll take ten days to reach the safety of Vekker's Crossing. Ayavah and other spellcasters have already sent messages south to the town so they know rough details of what happened and can make preparations to receive a mass of refugees much larger than their own town's population. The PCs' job during these ten days are to provide leadership, morale, entertainment, and discipline as needed to keep the refugees moving south.

Completing the Evacuation.name: Completing the Evacuation
Completing the Evacuation.text:
Completing the Evacuation

Completing the evacuation is a mythic deed—once the PCs complete the last evacuation obstacle (just before starting @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21902flight.JournalEntryPage.02event8return00]{Event 8}), restore 3 Mythic Points to each PC if the Eurythnians have at least 1 Survival Point remaining. In addition, grant the PCs 80 XP for completing the evacuation.

Event 7: Nightmare Attack.name: Event 7: Nightmare Attack
Event 7: Nightmare Attack.text:
Event 7: Nightmare Attack Moderate 13

Approximately halfway through the journey south from Xin-Eurythnia, the source of the PCs' nightmares makes themselves known after a sudden flare up of unsettling visions and fears that spreads through many of the Eurythnians. Use the campsite scene for this encounter, and allow the PCs to place themselves as they see fit.

Creatures: The source of these nightmares are a group of four entities from the Dimension of Time—misery siktemporas sent by the Ashen Man to torment the PCs, but also to serve as spies. Since the party's escape from his apocalyptic nightmares at the start of the adventure, the Ashen Man is keeping an eye on this group of adventurers who might possibly disrupt the doom he hopes will soon come to this world. Since the “game” of struggling against doomsday appeals to the Ashen Man, this (and several more to come during this campaign) ambush on the PCs is less an attempt to defeat them and more just to give the enigmatic, sadistic ancient one a bit of entertainment as he watches mortals struggle against inevitability. In time, as this campaign draws to a close, the Ashen Man will take personal steps to stop the PCs, but only once it becomes obvious they have a chance of actually disrupting his plans. Until then, the PCs remain entertaining (if underestimated) playthings.

Event 7: Nightmare Attack Moderate 13

@UUID[Actor.tNUy57s89t7oLjPv]{Misery Siktemporas (4)}

Unlike their leader's arrogant ambivalence toward the PCs, the four misery siktemporas are eager to finish the PCs off. Having spent several days “seasoning” their misery with tormenting nightmares, these extraplanar creatures manifest suddenly in the heart of the PCs' campsite, eager to inflict one last bout of pain and suffering to the party. One siktempora appears near each PC if possible, using @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.VlNcjmYyu95vOUe8]{Translocate} several times to swiftly close the distance from the outskirts to attack at precisely the right time—the siktemporas roll Dimension of Time Lore for their initiative checks to model their uncanny ability to know the precise moment to begin the attack.

If the PCs achieved a critical success during the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21902flight.JournalEntryPage.02theeurythnia00#nightmare-rumors-obstacle]{Nightmare Rumors} obstacle that takes place before this event, they have an inkling that the source of the peril is nearby. In this case, make sure the PCs know that they should be particularly vigilant during camp this night, and when the PCs roll Initiative as this event's combat begins, they do so at mythic proficiency as their destinies engage in their reactive defense. Even more importantly, their vigilance forces the siktemporas to begin the combat no closer than 35 feet to any one PC.

Once combat begins, each siktempora begins by using Uncanny Pounce. If they can @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.VlNcjmYyu95vOUe8]{Translocate} directly adjacent to a PC, they Strike, then Stride away before casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.XXqE1eY3w3z6xJCB]{Invisibility} to vex their foes, after which they move about the campsite and attempt claw Strikes and to Inflict Misery each round. If the PCs were vigilant, the siktemporas use Uncanny Pounce to Stride up to a target, then Strike, after which they attempt to Inflict Misery as their second action and then make a second claw Strike as their third action on that first round, eschewing the invisibility element of the attack. After the first round, one siktempora each round moves out of combat to inflict a Telepathic Wail on a random PC. The siktemporas fight to the death, after which the nightmares the party has been suffering cease.

Event 8: Return of the Risen.name: Event 8: Return of the Risen
Event 8: Return of the Risen.text:
Event 8: Return of the Risen Severe 13

With the completion of the tenth and final Evacuation obstacle, Dragon Sightings, the PCs are only a few hours away from reaching Vekker's Crossing, but one final peril strikes first, as those same dragons they spotted earlier in the day make their move! Use the Riverside scene for this encounter, and allow the PCs to place themselves anywhere they wish on the map as they travel just ahead of the bulk of the Eurythnians to scout out the land ahead.

Creatures: Just as the PCs confirm that Vekker's Crossing is only a few hours march away, bone-chilling roars rip through the air. From a cleft in the nearby mountain cliffs swoop a four dragons—three whom have been watching the PCs from afar and another larger one that the PCs haven't yet seen. Three of the dragons are adult mirage dragons, each of which is ridden by a humanoid figure—a risen runelord. The other dragon is a slightly larger ancient omen dragon. While the omen dragon is more powerful than any one mirage dragon, the mounted mirage dragons have the advantage of superior numbers; an instant after they appear, one of the mirage dragons blasts the omen dragon with a shimmering cone of vapor as his mounted runelord fires a green beam of energy (a disintegrate spell) at the larger omen dragon. While neither effect kills the omen dragon, they wound it significantly.

Panic strikes the Eurythnians, who begin to flee in all directions away from the area. While the omen dragon and its current foe continue their fight, clashing in the skies above, the remaining two mounted mirage dragons turn their attention to the PCs.

Event 8: Return of the Risen Severe 13

@UUID[Actor.H2FRgA6o2KZZ5X0J]{Krune} @UUID[Actor.omXFbjOuNak1A7Qw]{Krenlith} @UUID[Actor.LNIY8qr6FYyThe57]{Adult Mirage Dragons (2)}

Questions about how this mid-air battle began must wait. For now, the PCs face two risen runelords—Krenlith and Krune (once rulers of the kingdom of sloth, Haruka) and their mirage dragon mounts. A PC who attempts to Recall Knowledge can identify Runelord Krune with a successful @Check[arcana|dc:20|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check or a @Check[society|dc:22|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge]; those who achieve a critical success identify the more obscure to history Runelord Krenlith as well, along with a risen Runelord of Greed named Atharend who rides the third dragon now in combat with the omen dragon.

While the risen runelords ride dragons, their mounts are allies, not minions, and take their own actions each round as they attack the PCs. Each risen runelord must take an Interact action each round to maintain a grip on their mount, but otherwise they're free to act as they wish—typically by casting spells at the PCs. As long as a risen runelord remains alive, that runelord's dragon mount fights to the death, but if a risen runelord is slain, the associated mirage dragon flees the area once they are reduced to fewer than 50 Hit Points.

Krune and Krenlith have sloth spells prepared.

Meeting Kandirvek.name: Meeting Kandirvek
Meeting Kandirvek.text:
Meeting Kandirvek

Unexpected Attention

Unlike a typical infiltration, there's no upper limit to the number of Awareness Points the PCs can accrue during the evacuation, and the evacuation won't fail automatically upon reaching a certain Awareness Point tier. Only by reaching 0 Survival Points does the expedition come to a tragic end.

Instead, every time the evacuation accrues a multiple of 5 Awareness Points, the PCs face the following complication. (Certain events during Obstacles can also trigger this complication.)

Disaster! Complication

Trigger The PCs reach a multiple of 5 Awareness Points.

Overcome @Check[survival|dc:33] to know the best way to avoid the disaster, weapon strike against AC 35 to protect the Eurythnians, @Check[arcana|dc:35], @Check[nature|dc:35], @Check[occultism|dc:35] or @Check[religion|dc:35] to use magic to protect the Eurythnians, or @Check[perception|dc:36] check to spot the peril before it strikes

Whether it's an avalanche, a crumbling ledge, an unexpected but fierce blizzard, or a monster attack, some form of disaster threatens the safety of the Eurythnians!

Success You prevent the disaster from causing any deaths or loss of supplies.

Failure Choose one of the following: lose [[/r 1d6]] Survival Points or 2 Supply Points.

Critical Failure Lose [[/r 1d6]] Survival Points and 2 Supply Points.

As soon as the PCs defeat their foes, a death roar echoes down from above as the remaining mirage dragon spirals down from the clouds to slam into the nearby cliffs before tumbling lifeless to the ground. As the doomed dragon falls, his mounted runelord leaps free and attempts to fly to safety, only to be snapped up in the jaws of the gravely wounded omen dragon. With a single chomp, the omen dragon kills the remaining risen runelord, only to come to a harrowing, painful looking landing himself near the PCs. The omen dragon breathes heavily, shakes his head as if confused, but makes no further move at the moment—while he made his saving throw against Atharend's vanishing death aura, he's currently at a mere 40 Hit Points and is near death himself.

When the fight is over, the Eurythnians gather themselves but do not yet approach, leaving the PCs to be the first to make contact with the omen dragon. His name is Kandirvek, a dragon who has watched over Vekker's Crossing since the town's recent foundation. He explains that when he spotted the mirage dragons flying through the air in his territory, he initially thought they were readying to attack the town, so he swooped up to confront them.

Kandirvek gratefully accepts any healing the PCs provide him, then tells them to seek him out in his lair in the nearby mountains once they've finished escorting their refugees to town—he has much he wishes to discuss with them about “this new runelord cult.” If the PCs press him now, he nods toward the nervous Eurythnians, noting that as long as he remains nearby, the refugees have an increasing chance of panicking or reacting poorly, and again he asks the PCs to “deliver their charges to safety first” before seeking him out again. As soon as he can, Kandirvek takes once more to the skies and returns to his lair.

@UUID[Actor.LKgouoeb4eQIiq1n]{Kandirvek} Creature 14

  • huge

Investigating the Fallen.name: Investigating the Fallen
Investigating the Fallen.text:
Investigating the Fallen

The PCs can recover Krune's gear from where he and his dragon fell—or if he was slain and his dragon fled, one PC should spot Krune's body toppling lifeless from the dragon only to vanish in mid fall, leaving a wide leather belt to plummet to the ground.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.nASxliB1UwN8dhsU]{Krune's Belt}
This is a major retrieval belt that contains the following items in its pouches: a Cyrusian wand of never mind, a clear quartz crystal ball, and a triangular slab of pale green stone into which has been etched a complex star chart. A PC who examines the slab and succeeds at a @Check[nature|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge realizes two things—that the etchings seem to be magically created and that they depict the passage the Trinity Star took as it crossed through the sky a year ago. The slab is worth 1,500 gp as a curio but will be much more valuable to the PCs at the start of the next chapter.

Visiting a Dragon.name: Visiting a Dragon
Visiting a Dragon.text:
Visiting a Dragon

If the PCs follow Kandirvek's directions, they'll come to an unassuming valley about a four-hour hike northwest of Vekker's Crossing. Here, hidden behind a waterfall, is the cavern where the dragon has lived for decades. Kandirvek feels strangely compelled to offer aid to the PCs. As an omen dragon, he is no stranger to visions and divinatory dreams, and the faces of the PCs have been featuring prominently in those dreams of late—always in association with the region's legacy of ancient runelord rule. Until their recent encounter, he had nothing to go on, but now, he has more than an inkling.

When the PCs arrive, they find Kandirvek waiting for them in front of his cavern. He's used several potions from his hoard to heal his wounds, and when he notices the PCs' approach, he perks up, thanks them for their aid, and introduces himself again. He explains a little about his dreams, then asks the PCs for their story, eager to learn why the people of Xin-Eurythnia have fled their home.

As the PCs finish, Kandirvek speaks.

“As I mentioned, I have dreamt of you, the same as I've dreamt of these risen runelords. Be they ghosts roused from slumber or something else, it seems that the legacy of ancient Thassilon still claws at us from the distant past. In my dreams, I see you facing it, just as I recently witnessed you clash against two of the risen. I wish to provide what aid I can. The Kodar Mountains have long been my home, and I do not wish to see the runelords return to them any more than you do. Will you accept my aid?”

Again, this adventure assumes the PCs accept—if they don't, Kandirvek won't pressure them and wishes them luck. If they do, though, the omen dragon spreads his wings wide and stares down at the PCs as images and shapes begin to flicker and form in the folds of his wings. Over the course of the next 10 minutes, these shapes and colors coalesce into visions played out against the canopy of Kandirvek's prophetic wings in the form of a 6th-rank @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.41TZEjhO6D1nWw2X]{Augury} (for narrative purposes, assume the @Check[flat|dc:6] rolled to determine the augury's success is itself successful). His voice both deep and soothing, Kandirvek asks, “Where do the fates of these heroes cross with that of Thassilon's legacy?” The PCs witness the following portents in the dragon's wings, but the visions are distorted and faint. Each PC can attempt a @Check[perception|dc:32] check to discern the vision in greater detail—the party automatically observes the first vision below, and each successful Perception check thereafter reveals the next vision in order. If at least 3 PCs succeed at the check, all four visions are clear.

  • Vision 1: The PCs see themselves riding atop Kandirvek's back, flying above a vast mountain range while one of them consults the strange stone star chart, as if using it to navigate. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[mountain-lore|dc:25|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[survival|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge identifies the mountains as the central span of the Kodars.
  • Vision 2: The PCs see themselves clashing against immense, green-skinned giants. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[society|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] identifies these foes as powerful trolls.
  • Vision 3: The PCs see themselves floating down into a vast cavern where an ancient, ruined city sprawls. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] confirms the cavern is part of the Darklands realm of Nar-Voth; if they critically succeed, they realize it's the lost city of Xin-Cyrusian.
  • Vision 4: The PCs see themselves using magic to pry open a portal above the shattered remains of a stone well. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:30|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] identifies the well as a shattered runewell, and if they critically succeed, they realize it's the Runewell of Pride.

When the PCs observe their final vision, Kandirvek gasps in shock as the looming image of a regal man clad in peacock robes rises up to obscure the view and disrupt the portents granted by his prophetic wings. The man sneers and curtly waves his hand, and the vision comes to a sudden end. Kandirvek takes @Damage[15d6[mental]] damage (@Check[will|dc:50|basic] save). The PCs recognize Xanderghul if they succeed at a @Check[arcana|dc:25] or @Check[society|dc:27] check; on a critical success, they also discover that the disrupting vision was sent over a vast distance that spans the Great Beyond.

Kandirvek gratefully accepts any healing the PCs have to offer, though he fears that Xanderghul could strike at him again in the future. Rather than despair at this development, he promises to aid the PCs by carrying them to the location they saw in the vision, his resolve and conviction strengthened.

Where To Next?.name: Where To Next?
Where To Next?.text:
Where To Next?

Even if the PCs saw all four visions before Xanderghul cut them off, the exact location of their goal remains obscure. If the PCs recognized the nature of the third and fourth visions, they know their goal is Runelord Xanderghul's ruined city of Xin-Cyrusian, but the problem there is that the location of this city has been lost. It was once located somewhere in the southeast reach of what is now the Land of the Linnorm Kingdoms. The second vision supports this theory, as much of these lands are troll territory. If the PCs recognized the second and third visions, and if one of them succeeds at a @Check[society|dc:34] check, that PC recalls the existence of a site called the Throne of the Troll King—perhaps the most notorious location within the trolls' territory.

While this information is accurate and gets the PCs to the right place if they follow up on it, it might still seem like guesswork to the players. The key to completely understanding their destination lies in the pale green stone star chart the PCs (hopefully) recovered from risen Runelord Krune. This slab of stone presents a view of the sky that charts the path of the Trinity Star through the heavens. The chart is quite detailed, and a PC who spends an hour studying it and succeeds at a @Check[nature|dc:34] check realizes that the position of the stars combined with their knowledge of the Trinity Star's trajectory suggests it fell over a region close to the Throne of the Troll King.

If the PCs are struggling, Kandirvek can aid them by casting @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.rsZ5c0AUyywe5yoK]{Retrocognition} on the star chart. There's no chance of witnessing a traumatic or turbulent event, but if the caster sustains the spell for its maximum length of 10 minutes, they'll receive visions of the stone's journey. They watch it travel in risen Runelord Krune's possession from the underground ruins of Xin-Cyrusian, through a magical illusion that masks a hole in the cavern roof, out above the Throne of the Troll King, and then east to Krune's final confrontation with the PCs, whereupon the tablet was transferred into their control. Once the PCs have decided on their destination, Kandirvek offers to fly them there.

Reward: If the PCs figure out their destination is the Throne of the Troll King on their own without significant help from Kandirvek, grant them 40 XP.

Journey to the Truth.name: Journey to the Truth
Journey to the Truth.text:
Journey to the Truth

It's a 600 mile journey west from Vekker's Crossing to the Throne of the Troll King on Kandirvek's back. Once the PCs are ready to head out, he allows them to climb onto him and launches into the air, beginning the journey. At his fly speed of 180 feet, Kandirvek can cover the distance to the Throne of the Troll King in a few days, arriving at the location near sunset on the fourth day of travel. Each evening, Kandirvek selects a sheltered cave or valley to rest for the night.

Secrets of Pride.name: Secrets of Pride
Secrets of Pride.text:
Chapter 3: Secrets of Pride

With the Eurythnian refugees safe in Vekker's Crossing, the PCs are now free to follow up on the clues they've uncovered about the Risen of the Trinity Star. Though they don't know the cult's true motivations, they do know it's been working with seemingly revived runelords and that it engineered the destruction of Xin-Eurythnia. Ayavah can encourage the PCs to continue investigating if you need an NPC to give them a gentle push; she suggests they take Kandirvek up on his invitation to speak, as this could help them deduce what their next steps should be. This adventure assumes the PCs do so, but if they avoid this, you'll want to find a different way for them to learn that the Risen of the Trinity Star hail from the ruins of Xin-Cyrusian.

Event 9: Dragon Hunters.name: Event 9: Dragon Hunters
Event 9: Dragon Hunters.text:
Event 9. Dragon Hunters Moderate 14

Creatures: As the second day of travel draws to a close and the sun sets beyond the mountains to the west, Kandirvek swoops lower into a valley below to seek a good place to stop for the night. Unbeknownst to the PCs and dragon, they're spotted by a pair of deadly intruders: mythic monstrosities from the nightmare realm of Leng who became stranded in the mountains many years ago when Runelord Alaznist wreaked havoc on the Saga Lands' dimensions. These creatures are natbakhs, batlike monsters who count dragons among their favorite meals!

Event 9. Dragon Hunters Moderate 14

@UUID[Actor.NN8X7VcV1qME417c]{Natbakhs (2)}

The two natbakhs dart up from a cave below as Kandirvek approaches, swooping close to use their nightmare screeches on him and the PCs. On the following rounds, the deadly beasts focus their attacks on Kandirvek, lunging to bite him or lash at him with tentacles. As soon as they realize the PCs are dangerous as well, however, one natbakh focuses on a PC while the other fights Kandirvek.

Fortunately for PCs in danger of falling, this fight begins 200 feet off the ground. If a PC does fall, Kandirvek swoops down and lands nearby to minimize the risk flying poses to the other PCs (unless the PCs request he remain in the air), in which case both natbakhs swoop down and land as well.

On the first round of combat, Kandirvek uses Walk the Timelines. The PCs all remain mounted in one version, and this is the version of himself the dragon chooses as his location when the other vanishes at the end of the round. He uses Destiny Breath as often as possible, swooping close enough to use draconic frenzy against a natbakh on rounds where he cannot.

Fighting from Dragonback

During Event 9, the PCs fight a pair of mythic foes while riding a dragon. While PCs capable of flight are free to leap off the dragon to join the battle in the air, those who must remain atop Kandirvek follow the rules for mounted attacks (Player Core 437). Kandirvek acts on his own initiative, so no PC needs to Command an Animal to direct him, nor do he or the PCs share a multiple attack penalty.

A PC who doesn't have the Ride feat (or a similar mounted combat skill, at the GM's discretion) must Interact at least once per round to cling to the dragon's body—those who don't are thrown from the dragon and fall.

Remember as well that both Kandirvek and the natbakhs must spend at least one action per round Flying to avoid falling.

Once the natbakhs are defeated, Kandirvek chooses to rest in their former cavern for the night. The cave is unsettling and smells foul, but PCs who choose to camp near its entrance instead do not need to fear being attacked in the middle of the night.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.V3GAZUerDhsPpiJ5]{Remains}
The natbakhs weren't particularly interested in gathering treasure, but among the remains (including a significant number of smaller dragon corpses) is a scattering of various trinkets, art objects, and other valuables worth a total of 700 gp. Among these valuables are two additional treasures worth quite a bit more: a greater sturdy shield and a pair of greater boots of bounding.

Throne of the Troll King.name: Throne of the Troll King
Throne of the Troll King.text:
Throne of the Troll King

Kandirvek's Choice

The encounters that await the PCs below the Throne of the Troll King are deadly and pose an even greater threat to their non-mythic dragon companion. Kandirvek shouldn't be put in this peril, though, unless the PCs insist he follows them. In this case, he agrees to remain up topside to guard the entrance to the lost city should any of the other trolls try to come after the PCs. While he can't overcome their regeneration, his threatening size and presence is enough to deter the trolls from following the PCs, as the vast majority of them are standard forest trolls who'll struggle to hurt Kandirvek even if he ignores them.

Ultimately, if Kandirvek accompanies the PCs below, there's no real risk that the trolls will claim control, but there is a very real chance that the dragon might perish in the dangerous encounters. If the PCs push, Kandirvek could even use Prophetic Wings to reveal to the PCs what he already fears—that if he goes with them into the lost city of Xin-Cyrusian, he'll likely die... or worse!

After the fight with the natbakhs, the PCs shouldn't face other serious threats for the rest of their journey. As they approach the Throne of the Troll King, Kandirvek touches down on a mountaintop overlooking the site. Even from afar, the immense stone throne sitting at the peak of the tallest foothill in the area is impressive, as is the astounding number of trolls that dwells in the surrounding hills. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[society|dc:25|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge remembers a local legend that claims that anyone who sits on the throne overnight at midwinter can command the trolls of the region to obey them for a year. If the PC rolls a critical success on this check, they instead suspect the truth. In Thassilonian times, this throne was a rune giant's seat of power, and it was her authority over “lesser giants” that granted her command over the region's trolls, not any intrinsic feature of the throne itself. That the throne has persisted over the ages without eroding is more due to the nature of Thassilonian preservative magic than anything else.

While there are thousands of trolls in the region, a much smaller number stand guard at the peak of the hill. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:32] check from afar notices one thing of note—the troll who appears to be the leader of the throne guards wears flowing, colorful emerald robes accented and wields a flaming bec de corbin. The similarity to the gear of the Trinity acolytes the PCs faced in the Dawnsilver workshop should be a clear indication that the Risen of the Trinity Star have indeed been active here!

Kandirvek suggests swooping down to make an intimidating arrival. He'll drop the PCs off at the top of the hill, then set to the skies above, roaring and periodically darting down to use his Destiny Breath or jaws and claws against the trolls in the surrounding area. While the trolls can regenerate this damage, the unexpected attack from an enormous dragon they can't fly after is fearsome enough to keep the PCs from having to face an unending parade of reinforcements as they deal with the trolls gathered around the throne.

Guardians of the Throne.name: Guardians of the Throne
Guardians of the Throne.text:
Guardians of the Throne Severe 14

At the crown of this flat-topped hill is a single massive stone chair, sized as if crafted for a person who'd stand at least forty feet tall. Unsettling totems made of bones, leather, and fur propped up by wooden poles stand vigil around the throne, each bearing a distorted face that stares away from the throne and into the surrounding hills. The throne sits atop a slab of stone that rises five feet from the surrounding area. The surface of this slab—as well as the area of dirt surrounding it–is blackened and looks melted almost to the sheen of glass in places, but the throne itself appears pristine and new.

This hilltop is the site the Trinity Star struck a year ago, destroying the original throne and punching through the hilltop into the deep cavern below. The Trinity Star's supernatural passage scorched the ground and turned some of the grit into glass as it blasted through, but it didn't create a crater. The throne as it appears now is a permanent illusory object placed there by Xanderghul. A person who enters the throne's space falls through the illusion into the hidden shaft beneath it, and into a dangerous trap; see “Investigating the Throne ” on page 50 for more details.

Use the Throne of the Troll King scene.

Creatures: Trolls have long regarded this throne as an object of cultural fear and wonder, so when the Trinity Star struck it a year or so ago, panic swept over them. The bravest of them, a troll wizard named Gavergash, was the first to investigate, and he fell victim to the Hidden Halls. Yet rather than remain in that illusory labyrinth forever, he emerged ever more powerful—after becoming Xanderghul's pawn. He created the illusory throne to mask its destruction, then took up the role of its protector while Xanderghul recovered from his ordeal in the ruins of Xin-Cyrusian. Though Xanderghul has since moved on, Gavergash knows there are things below that the runelord's enemies could potentially use against him, and as such, he maintains his vigil here.

Gavergash called the troll warleaders he trusted most to his side, and for the past year, he has continued to watch over the hilltop with a dedication that borders on obsessive. Few legitimate challengers have come to the throne to face him. More significant have been the explorers who stumbled into the region in search of the Trinity Star—unfortunates whom Gavergash made certain never escaped to tell any tales. Their bones, flesh, and skin now adorn the numerous totems that decorate the hilltop, serving as macabre warnings for any who dare venture near.

Guardians of the Throne Severe 14

@UUID[Actor.BL0mB5UFB9OYxxgt]{Gavergash} @UUID[Actor.e8JfMvty6AuELtKf]{Troll Warleaders (8)}

Even with their draconic ally, the PCs don't particularly impress Gavergash at first, but as soon as he realizes they also have mythic power, he understands that this is his true test. He orders his troll war leaders to focus their attacks on the PC who was the most dangerous on any previous round and starts combat by activating Empty Robes from his hollow robes, so that he can activate Hollow Target to defend himself. He prefers to cast spells in combat, starting with fly to grant himself better mobility. He also likes to fight next to a totem, so that when enough PCs draw near, he can use Awaken Totem after casting a spell. Gavergash fights to the death, as do his followers for as long as he still lives. If Gavergash is defeated, the remaining trolls race to claim his bec de corbin to become the “new leader,” as this weapon has become a symbol of fear among the local trolls due to its twinned powers of fire and lightning. Faced with foes who can efficiently negate their regeneration, the troll warleaders flee the area entirely if both Gavergash and at least half the remaining trolls are dead.

Investigating the Throne.name: Investigating the Throne
Investigating the Throne.text:
Investigating the Throne Moderate 14

The dotted red circle indicates the border of the 800-foot-deep shaft the Trinity Star left in its wake when it burned through the throne. Normally, a PC who steps into this area (perhaps after mistaking the illusory throne for the real thing) would fall into the hole and land at the heart of the crater below (a 1,000 foot fall in all). The Trinity Star's passage, however, transformed this shaft into a dangerous hazard. The first to succumb to it was Gavergash, and though he emerged more powerful (if under Xanderghul's control), those who follow him face an entirely different fate.

Note that if the PCs are accompanied by Kandirvek, he may be permanently lost to this dangerous legacy of the Trinity Star, as he is a non-mythic creature.

Scene Notes Ambience

Investigating the Throne Moderate 14

@UUID[Actor.wMqXpwQfTjPYI31f]{A Falling Star's Memories}

Hazard: The shaft walls vanish and are replaced by an endless field of stars in all direction, as if the viewer were suddenly lost in outer space.

Reward: Overcoming this trap is a mythic deed; doing so restores 3 Mythic Points to each PC.

The Ruins of Xin-Cyrusian.name: The Ruins of Xin-Cyrusian
The Ruins of Xin-Cyrusian.text:
The Ruins of Xin-Cyrusian

Whether they endure A Falling Star's Memories and come out the other side in the crater at the heart of Xin-Cyrusian or disable the trap and emerge through the hole in the cavern's roof 200 feet above the crater proper, the PCs' first glimpse of what was once the greatest city in all Thassilon is unforgettable.

Here lies the broken core of the fabled city of Xin-Cyrusian, the mystery of its location finally revealed. When Earthfall struck, its violent aftershocks caused rifts to open and sent a significant portion of the city crumbling down into the planet's depths, where it was buried beneath the collapse of the mountains above it. Immense protective wards shielded the heart of Xin-Cyrusian from being totally destroyed but resulted in the city's core being buried deep in the Darklands, where it has remained for thousands of years. Over time, Darklands denizens came to dwell in the cavern. Some of these took up the worship of Runelord Xanderghul's old persona, the Peacock Spirit, while others were exposed to sources of mythic power.

Scene Notes Ambience

@UUID[Playlist.RN0Zhxpmp9tFJqhO.PlaylistSound.dAWdjw2t171bpInD]{The Ruins of Xin-Cyrusian}

While the size and scope of these ruins may seem daunting at first, Xanderghul's soul left a blatant trail for the PCs to follow as it moved from the crater southeast to his mostly buried palace. There are a few significant side encounters the PCs can explore for more context and resources, but the bulk of the creatures dwelling in these ruins are non-mythic and lower than 12th level. Some of these might give the PCs XP here and there, but by and large, these denizens (which include, but aren't limited to, greater shadows, sinspawns, enormous spiders and other monstrous cave animals, undead trolls, and will-o'-wisps) avoid the PCs and flee combat when confronted.

The entire cavern is dimly lit by ancient illusory magic that once gave the city an almost overwhelming glow at night, as well as by patches of bioluminescent fungus growing on the cave roof that mimic the view of a starry sky. Xin-Cyrusian's once-fine streets are riddled with cracks and strewn with rubble, particularly near areas where large pillars of stone have formed over the eons; these areas are difficult terrain to traverse. Most of the buildings are one- or two-story stone structures—very few remain that have more floors than that, except as noted in the text.

The Crater.name: The Crater
The Crater.text:
C1. The Crater

This immense cavern flickers and shimmers with all manner of light, its ceiling two hundred feet above filled with scattered, glowing points not that different from stars on a clear night. Below, many of the ancient buildings shimmer with ghostly radiance. Vast fields of rubble and immense pillars of stone bury and pierce entire sections of the city, making it seem as though the city had been transposed through magic into an underground chamber not quite large enough to contain it. At the heart of the ruins, a fresh-looking crater nearly two hundred and fifty feet in diameter further mars the ruins. A jagged mound of iron shards lies heaped at the center of the crater, while a fifty-foot-wide path of melted stone and cracked glass winds out of it toward the east. Slightly glowing footprints shimmer in the middle of this path, leading away from the crater as if a person stepped out of the iron fragments and simply walked away.

A successful @Check[athletics|dc:20] check is required to clamber up the steep, crumbling sides of the crater. A PC who investigates the site and succeeds at a @Check[nature|dc:20|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge deduces that, based on the crater's size and shape, the force of the impact must have been magically contained to minimize the damage dealt to the city—to say nothing of the fact that the star was capable of boring through 800 feet of solid stone.

A PC who spends an action Seeking the iron rubble notices that the mass seems to have been a roughly spherical ball of iron that splintered into dozens of fragments, exposing a now empty, hollow interior that looks disturbingly like that of a human curled into a fetal position. Further investigation requires pursuit of the following activity.

Investigate the Rubble

  • Concentrate
  • Exploration

The PC spends ten minutes examining the iron rubble's magical nature, then attempts a @Check[arcana|dc:34], @Check[nature|dc:34], @Check[occultism|dc:34], or @Check[religion|dc:34] check (or @Check[perception|dc:37] check). At the end of each investigation, compare the amount of Victory Points the PCs have earned overall for this activity and share any information they've accumulated with them.

Critical Success The PCs earn 2 Victory Points.

Success The PCs earn 1 Victory Point.

Critical Failure The shattered iron shimmers with prismatic energy an instant before unleashing a blast of radiance out into the area. The PC takes @Damage[(10d10)[spirit]] damage (@Check[will|dc:32|basic] save).

1 Victory Point The rubble only appears to be made of iron—in fact, it's a single immense (but shattered) warshard that was once part of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.88vRw2ZVPax4hhga]{Gorum}'s body.

3 Victory Points The massive warshard smashed into an object that has been mostly obliterated, but enough fragments remain to confirm that the thing the warshard struck was the source of the explosion that created the crater, not the warshard's impact.

5 Victory Points The object destroyed by the warshard was a powerful magic statue. At this point, the PCs have managed to piece together enough of its fragments to determine that the statue was once of a human, whom they can identify as Runelord Xanderghul with a successful @Check[arcana|dc:20|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[society|dc:25|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge. A PC who critically succeeds determines something more astounding: this statue was Runelord Xanderghul's anima focus—a magical anchor of sorts linked to the runelord's Runewell of Pride. With the anima focus destroyed, the entrance to the demiplane linked to the Runewell of Pride has been cut off (although it's possible a “back door” into the demiplane still exists somewhere).

Reward: Grant the PCs 10 XP for each Victory Point they earn, for a total of 50 XP if they earn all 5. Grant them an additional 30 XP if they identify the anima focus's remains properly.

Xanderghul's Path.text:
C1a. Xanderghul's Path

When Runelord Xanderghul's spirit emerged from the Trinity Star, he lacked a physical body, despite the imprint his soul left within the cracked warshard. Infused with raw power from the star that had carried him home, he returned to his palace to the southeast, his presence scorching and searing the ground and buildings around him so that he left a fifty-foot-wide path through the ruins. Even more curious are the bare human footprints that lead down the middle of the path. Left in the ground as if someone strode through mud that then hardened to stone, these prints shimmer and flicker with radiant light.
Xanderghul's Path.name: Xanderghul's Path

Dragon Guardians.name: Dragon Guardians
Dragon Guardians.text:
C2. Dragon Guardians Severe 14

Creatures: Once the PCs set out into the ruins, a small group of mirage dragons takes note of the newcomers to the area. These four are allies of the dragons the PCs encountered (and likely killed) near Vekker's Crossing. They expect their missing allies to return soon, and while their shared nest is farther down a long tunnel in area C2, they've been watching over the central cavern in shifts.

C2. Dragon Guardians Severe 14

@UUID[Actor.gLmrH4MeoQq4NyAe]{Adult Mirage Dragons (4)}

Unless the PCs take special precautions to remain stealthy, they're noticed as soon they enter the cavern by one of these dragons, who launches up off their perch on a ruined building to the southeast of area @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21903secret.JournalEntryPage.03thecrater00000]{C1} to confront them. When the dragon lifts off the rooftop, it roars a challenge to draw the PCs' attention and alert their friends in area C2. The first dragon lands about 50 feet away from the PCs, while the other three arrive within a minute. The dragons don't initiate combat, and the first one to approach is obviously motivated by curiosity rather than aggression. If the PCs decide to fight the dragons, use the Xin-Cyrusian Streets map scene for the fight. In this case, the dragons fight until one of them is reduced to fewer than 80 HP, at which point all the dragons flee back to their nest in area C2. Confronted there, the dragons fight to the death; use the Dragon Nest scene for this fight.

Restless and in desperate need of both news about their allies and simple entertainment, the dragons are more interested in conversation than combat. The first dragon to reach the PCs introduces themself as Sifodian and warns them that their allies— Itharial, Noruvikiz, and Yivnisbrell—will be here shortly, but that they don't want to fight. They merely want to talk, and given the chance, they ask the PCs about their lives and accomplishments. If the PCs agree to speak to the dragons, the four settle in on building perches around the party, trading information about the Risen in exchange for entertaining anecdotes—play this encounter out using the Influence rules (Pathfinder GM Core 187). The PCs have three 10-minute rounds to influence the dragons before they grow bored; if the PCs fail to reach Influence 6 with the dragons by the end of the third round, the four dragons attack.
