Will +25

Discovery @Check[dragon-lore|dc:32|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover], @Check[society|dc:34|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover], @Check[perception|dc:37|traits:concentrate,secret,action:discover|name:Discover]

Influence Skills @Check[performance|dc:32|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (to entertain the dragons), @Check[arcana|dc:34|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence] (to know how to best talk to dragons), @Check[intimidation|dc:35|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence], @Check[diplomacy|dc:37|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence], @Check[deception|dc:38|traits:concentrate,linguistic,action:influence|name:Influence]

Influence 1 Sifodian was the first mirage dragon to arrive here, but the others came very soon thereafter. They number seven in all—one for each of the arms of the Sihedron. Three of their allies left the ruins several days ago, however, on an important mission to track down some “troublemakers.”

Influence 2 The dragons settled into their lair here not quite a year ago after being contacted in their dreams by a woman who claimed to have found her way into the Eye of Arrogance, Runelord Xanderghul's ancient demiplane within his Runewell of Pride. The woman's call went out to several mirage dragons in the region, as Xanderghul had valued their aid long ago, and the magic of the Eye of Arrogance remained aligned with mirage dragon dreams.

Influence 4 The woman who called the dragons to Xin-Cyrusian was named Aethusa, and she was served by a small army of various humans who called themselves the Risen of the Trinity Star. The name “Aethusa,” one of the dragons notes, was the name of two different runelords back in old Thassilonian times; they observe that several of the Risen also used the names of long-dead runelords. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:25|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[society|dc:25|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge recognizes the name Aethusa as having been the name of the third runelord of gluttony and the sixth runelord of greed, while a critical success also allows the PC to recall that, more recently, a woman from Xin-Edasseril took this name and claimed to be the reincarnation of both these runelords. This latest Aethusa has earned a reputation as a troublemaker in western New Thassilon but hasn't been seen in several months. Most believe she'd finally been captured and imprisoned, or that she'd been executed by Runelord Belimarius.

Influence 6 Most of the Risen of the Trinity Star have left these ruins, along with Aethusa. The dragons weren't included in the cult's plans and were left behind along with some of the other Risen, who continue to live in the southeastern part of the ruins. Some of these, the dragons overheard, were to travel east to Xin-Shalast (the dragons use the old name for the city now known as Xin-Eurythnia), but most of them went in the other direction “to gather more of the ancients' relics.” The dragons aren't sure what that means, and this too plays a part in their growing discontent with Aethusa.

Influence 8 The dragons are delighted with the PCs and extend to them a rare privilege: they are invited to their nest in area C2 and may each pick out a single treasure from the dragons' shared hoard as a prize. While the PCs might be wary of this, the dragons are being honest in their offer.

Resistances If the PCs mention that they killed mirage dragons or otherwise make it clear that they're the reason the other dragons haven't yet returned, increase all Influence DCs by 5 for the rest of the encounter. If the PCs make it clear that the risen runelords who rode those dragons are also dead, though, this DC increase lowers to just 2.

Weaknesses The dragons particularly enjoy stories about the PCs making mistakes and somehow still managing to succeed—a PC who includes examples of this sort of failing forward during their check gains a +2 circumstance bonus to their roll.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.ZmB9uLkjIFkbKsch]{Dragon's Nest}
The dragons' nest is in a cul-de-sac cavern to the southeast of the central crater. If the PCs kill the dragons, they'll be able to loot as much of their treasure hoard as they want, but if they reached Influence 8, the dragons allow each PC to select a single prize as payment for their entertainment. The hoard consists of their shared treasures and includes coins and art objects and gems worth a total of 4,000 gp (no one object is worth more than 1,000 gp, though). It also contains a bejeweled dawnsilver scroll tube worth 2,000 gp that contains the formula for the band of heroes ritual that the dragons consider a single item for a pick, a +2 greater resilient chain shirt, a major staff of phantasms, a 6th-rank Cyrusian wand of vision of death, and a major charm of electricity resistance.

Rewards: If the mirage dragons depart on friendly terms with the PCs, award the party XP as if they defeated the dragons in combat, and grant each PC 1 Mythic Point for this legendary achievement.

Abandoned Campsite.name: Abandoned Campsite
Abandoned Campsite.text:
C3. Abandoned Campsite Moderate 14

Nestled in the ruins near the strange path of scorched and melted stone are the scattered remains of a campsite.

This section of the ruins was used as a campsite by Aethusa when she first ventured down into Xin-Cyrusian. The site was originally concealed by magic, but its protections evaporated when she became possessed by Xanderghul during the first night she spent here. While most of her belongings were taken by Xanderghul, he didn't bother with the mundane detritus of her camp, among which are pages from Aethusa's journals, research notes, and the like. If the PCs spend some time gathering these up, these pages can provide them some important insight into the situation they now face. See @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21903secret.JournalEntryPage.03aethusasnote00]{Aethusa's Notes} below. Before the PCs can investigate the site safely, though, they'll be reminded of the perils the Darklands holds.

C3. Abandoned Campsite Moderate 14

@UUID[Actor.TwQ0OozjOCqFTCYr]{Cave Worm} @UUID[Actor.dVRS6IrKpfwqqDVH]{Shulns (3)}

Creatures: A few moments after the PCs enter this area (either just as they're about to leave or a minute or so into their first search of the ruined camp), the ground suddenly trembles. A moment later, an immense cave worm bursts from the ground with a thunderous roar. The cave worm attacks the PCs immediately, but at the start of the second round, more creatures erupt from the ground as well—a pack of three shulns who have been hunting the cave worm. The shulns initially attack the cave worm, but once the worm is dead, any surviving shulns turn their attention to the PCs.

This fight is loud and destructive, as the immense monsters crash and rage through the area. Though the PCs might be tempted to let them fight, you should make sure to describe the damage these enormous monsters are causing the campsite as they thrash and burrow. At the start of each round of this fight, the DCs to investigate the area for Aethusa's notes increase by 1.

The cave worm fights to the death. The shulns fight until only one of the three remains standing, at which point the lone survivor flees once it's brought below 50 Hit Points.

Aethusa's Notes.name: Aethusa's Notes
Aethusa's Notes.text:
Aethusa's Notes

Once the giant monsters are dealt with, the PCs can attempt to collect Aethusa's journal entries and piece together her role in the founding of the Risen of the Trinity Star by pursuing the following activity.

Search the Campsite

  • Concentrate
  • Exploration

The PC spends ten minutes examining the campsite, gathering and collating the notes left behind, and then reading through them. The PC attempts a @Check[academia-lore|dc:32] check, a @Check[arcana|dc:34] check, or a @Check[perception|dc:37] check. At the end of each investigation, compare the amount of Victory Points the PCs have earned overall for this activity and reveal any information they've accumulated.

Critical Success The PCs earn 2 Victory Points.

Success The PCs earn 1 Victory Point.

Critical Failure The search causes the sudden collapse of rubble that was weakened during the monster fight. The PC takes @Damage[(10d10)[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:32] save).

1 Victory Point @UUID[Actor.hRFn9d6Z34rRHBR3]{Campsite Satchel}
Journal pages written by Aethusa detail mysterious dreams of a cloaked figure who told her about the power she could claim from Xanderghul's hidden Runewell of Pride. She believes that these messages are from one of her past lives as a runelord of Thassilon. The description of the cloaked figure matches the appearance of the Ashen Man, whom the PCs encountered at the start of this adventure. The PCs also discover a leather satchel that contains 300 gp in rare incense.

3 Victory Points @UUID[Actor.XEz3xHQo62NhJvGJ]{Campsite Scroll}
More pages expound upon Aethusa's increasingly vivid dreams and her discovery that the Trinity Star struck the Throne of the Troll King. Other entries explain how the site's troll guardians seemed to expect her arrival and did not stand in her way when she set about studying the throne and discovered it was an illusion covering a mysterious shaft into the ground. These entries end with her excitedly theorizing that the ruins of lost Xin-Cyrusian might lie somewhere below. The PCs also discover a 7th-rank scroll of teleport.

5 Victory Points @UUID[Actor.4Ov7y75MQJzS5wxb]{Campsite Wand}
The final pages contain accounts of Aethusa's eerie experiences in the Fallen Star's memories, her discovery of the destroyed anima focus, and her decision to press on toward the southwest and follow the strange trail left by “whoever, or whatever, emerged from the Trinity Star.” She also notes a strange dream she had the night before she entered the ruins, of meeting Runelord Xanderghul and being promised some sort of secret knowledge, only to have awoken too early. In her final, most recent entry, she expresses a desire to repeat the dream as she camps in the ruins for the first time. The PCs also discover a widening wand of phantasmal calamity.

Ruined Palace.name: Ruined Palace
Ruined Palace.text:
C4. Ruined Palace Severe 14

What was once a vast, beautiful palace lies mostly buried by stone. Only the structure's outer wall and gate and the shimmering facade of what must have once been a breathtaking structure remain today. Within the outer wall's gate glimmers a rippling silver portal of mirror-like energy, its reflections distorted and shuddering.

Once Xanderghul's palace, little remains of the structure today apart from its facade. After the anima focus's destruction, Xanderghul traveled here to take advantage of the lingering defensive magic in the palace. Harnessing it, he used it to create a back door into the Eye of Arrogance, where he spent the first month of his recovery and from which he managed to possess Aethusa. Now that Xanderghul has moved on, he's left behind some of his original converts and creations to guard this legacy—more out of habit than out of any real concern that the palace might be looted. He's taken the real treasures with him, yet in his overwhelming pride, he neglected to account for some elements the PCs can use against him.

The rippling mirror-like field of energy is a portal into the Eye of Arrogance. Known as the Mirror of Glory, it's detailed below.

C4. Ruined Palace Severe 14

@UUID[Actor.PbrUlDv9mN0HR2b5]{Pridespawn Sentinels (6)}

Creatures: Like the greedspawn soldiers the PCs encountered earlier in this adventure, a group of powerful pridespawn stand vigil here. Loyal to Xanderghul, they fight to the death. Use the C4. Ruined Palace scene for this encounter.

Mirror of Glory.name: Mirror of Glory
Mirror of Glory.text:
C4a. Mirror of Glory Moderate 14

Xanderghul's Palace is ruined, and anything of value that remained accessible in the small portions that still exist have long since been looted or taken by Xanderghul himself when he relocated to the Emerald Chambers. The only significant point of interest is the sheet of rippling reflective energy that fills the open archway in the palace gatehouse. This is the Mirror of Glory, a jury-rigged portal into the Eye of Arrogance that Xanderghul created after his main route for entry via the anima focus and the Runewell of Pride was destroyed by his return to Golarion. While the Mirror of Glory allows access to what was once the heart of Xanderghul's power, it's also an incredibly dangerous mythic hazard. When the PCs examine the archway and the portal more closely, after they've defeated the sinspawn guarding it, read or paraphrase the following.

Peacock carvings adorn the sides of this archway, their tail feathers curving upward. A line of runes glows softly on the keystone above where the tail feathers meet and wrap around a colorful cubic gemstone embedded in the stone. No gate remains in the archway—instead, the opening is filled with a reflective wall that looks almost like a vertical sheet of quicksilver. The wall distorts and ripples its reflections, and shimmers of prismatic energy play back and forth over the surface, yet through these ripples and shimmers, what's reflected within appears glorious and beautiful.

The runes on the archway's keystone read, in Thassilonian: “Behold the glory of he who is as great as the gods.” The cubic gemstone embedded in the keystone is a powerful mythic magic item known as a paradigm cube and helps to power the Mirror of Glory.

Hazard: When the PCs gaze into the Mirror of Glory, they see their reflections as if they were dressed in the finest raiments, cleaned and coiffed as though they were attending a royal gala. In place of armor are magnificent gowns and coats, and in place of weapons, the reflected PCs carry regalia and fans made of peacock feathers. Furthermore, rather than reflecting a ruined city, the image shows a grand hall in a palace. A moment later, the PCs' reflections take on lives of their own: they step aside, turn away from the PCs, and bow down before a resplendent figure that materializes beyond them. It's as though this same figure were appearing out of nowhere behind the PCs even as they stare into the reflection. Any PC who glances over their shoulder sees no figure there. It takes only a @Check[arcana|dc:15|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] or @Check[society|dc:20|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] to Recall Knowledge to recognize this figure as the most powerful of the legendary rulers of ancient Thassilon: Runelord Xanderghul.

C4a. Mirror of Glory Moderate 14

@UUID[Actor.OlJzrwwyC6rdgkMD]{Mirror of Glory}

Xanderghul could grant them permission to pass through the Mirror of Glory into the Eye of Arrogance, but before the PCs can do so, they must first disable or destroy the hazardous portion of the portal. The Mirror of Glory is similar in some ways to the Endless Realities trap the PCs encountered earlier in this adventure—had the PCs not been exposed to this lesser version of one of Xanderghul's favorite ways to keep enemies imprisoned and controlled, the Mirror of Glory's effects on them would be even greater than those presented here! (At your discretion, if an NPC is exposed to the Mirror, increase all Disable and saving throw DCs by 5 to account for this potency—another example where their dragon ally Kandirvek is wise to avoid accompanying the PCs into Xin-Cyrusian!)

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.XnNnoIQvaQ5WX3ux]{Keystone}
The paradigm cube embedded in the keystone falls undamaged to the ground once the Mirror of Glory is fully deactivated.

Reward: Overcoming this trap is a mythic deed; doing so restores 3 Mythic Points to each PC.

Traversing the Mirror of Glory.name: Traversing the Mirror of Glory
Traversing the Mirror of Glory.text:
Traversing the Mirror of Glory

Once the PCs disable the Mirror of Glory or destroy the archway that frames it, the shimmering field stabilizes and no longer distorts reality. At the same time, the PCs have a shared insight into the mirror's function and immediately recognize that it's now a portal that's safe to traverse—a “back door” into the Eye of Arrogance.

When the PCs step into the portal, they share an identical set of visions during their transition from Xin-Cyrusian into the Eye of Arrogance. Their mythic destinies interact with Xanderghul's legacy to grant them insights into the runelord's mind. When you describe these visions, do so to the group as a whole to save time, but explain that from each PC's individual perspective, they appear in these visions as an idealized version of their mythic destiny—what they might look like, in game terms, at 20th level. These manifestations of themselves introduces each vision, as if the PC themselves were bestowing these insights on them from the future. If you have four players, pick one each to serve as the “voice” that introduces each vision.

Vision 1: “Runelord Xanderghul returns to the Universe and takes the graciously offered body of a minor wizard named Aethusa.” A blond woman triumphantly descends via magical flight into the ruined underground city of Xin-Cyrusian. She examines the crater, takes copious notes, then moves into the city itself before setting up a campsite. She erects magical defenses around the site before going to sleep, after which a ghostly shape the PCs can make out as Xanderghul, if they succeed at a @Check[perception|dc:32] check, easily moves through them and then flows into Aethusa's slumbering form. Her body awakens and laughs in triumph, her eyes shimmering with radiant energy.

Vision 2: “Runelord Xanderghul lays claim to the tomb of his beloved friend, the late Emperor Xin, to proceed with his visionary purpose for Golarion.” Aethusa moves through a crypt. While the PCs can't make out exact details, they know that the objects she plucks from biers and open sarcophagi are the bones and burial raiments of long-dead runelords. A moment later, the vision shifts to show Aethusa performing a ritual, accompanied by figures dressed in the raiments of the Risen of the Trinity Star, over a pile of dusty bones. A figure rises from those bones—Runelord Gimmel, whom the PCs fought earlier in this adventure. As he bows before Aethusa, the vision ends.

Vision 3: “Runelord Xanderghul summons the faithful to follow him once more and returns to new but nostalgic flesh.” Several Risen of the Trinity Star carry a human figure wrapped in vibrant-colored cloth into a large room where Aethusa lies unconscious amid magical apparatuses and four immense steel vats. The Risen place the body near Aethusa, and from her body rises the ghostly form of Xanderghul, who then flows into the wrapped body. A moment later, that body tears free from its shroud and the Risen clothe and adorn the reborn Xanderghul in his traditional robes and armaments. Aethusa, still unconscious, is taken away from the room while Xanderghul blesses each of those in attendance with a touch to the brow before leading them out of the chamber.

Vision 4: “Runelord Xanderghul opens a Doomsday Door to start the process of attaining his well-deserved godhood and lay waste to the undeserving wretches of the Saga Lands.” Xanderghul stands in a cavern, attended by several Risen of the Trinity Star. He raises his arms before an enormous door. The door creaks open, and the earth shakes as an image of the Oliphaunt of Jandelay surges out of the door, slaying the Risen. As the Oliphaunt rears up, Xanderghul clambers onto its back. The cavern opens above as sunlight and a cascade of rubble smash down to bury the door. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[perception|dc:32] check catches a glimpse of Runelord Xanderghul and Sorshen locked in battle as they are whisked away through the doors, along with the Oliphaunt, the instant before they slam shut and are buried in rubble.

The Eye of Arrogance.name: The Eye of Arrogance
The Eye of Arrogance.text:
The Eye of Arrogance Severe 14

Once the PCs experience the four visions, they emerge on the other side of the portal into Runelord Xanderghul's mostly abandoned demiplane, the Eye of Arrogance. If the PCs all entered the portal at about the same time, they manifest in adjacent squares beside a similar portal, simultaneously, within the demiplane. Take time to read or paraphrase the encounter's read-aloud text below, after which the portal's guardians act swiftly and attack.

The Eye of Arrogance is a finite demiplane, whose borders exist as shown on the nearby map. Within this demiplane, gravity and time function normally. The air within the Eye of Arrogance is breathable, but it carries distracting scents that work to undermine the mind's convictions—when the demiplane was fully functional, this had a much more debilitating effect, but now that the place is damaged and Xanderghul has moved on, it only imparts a –1 status penalty to all Will saves made by intruders inside the demiplane; this is an emotion and mental effect.

When the PCs emerge into the Eye of Arrogance, they do so simultaneously as a group, appearing in the middle of the area between the destroyed Runewell of Pride and Runelord Xanderghul's throne. Read or paraphrase the following at this time.

This realm appears as a beautiful, opulent garden full of lush, green plant life and hundreds of brilliant flowers. Iridescent peacocks strut about the garden nonchalantly, occasionally letting out a soft squawk. Above shine what appear to be the stars of a night sky, yet the garden is well lit as if from the light of the noonday sun. Twin rows of five thirty-foot-tall statues of Runelord Xanderghul line the sides of the garden, looking down at those below with different expressions of imperious disdain over a row of rose bushes in full bloom. To one side of the rose bushes, a stone platform rises five feet from the manicured lawn, atop which stand four more statues of Runelord Xanderghul arrayed around a majestic throne with a back made of gemstones arranged as if they were peacock tail feathers.

At the far end of the garden from the throne is what appears to be a shattered stone well, its rocky fragments suspended in midair as though in the split second after its explosion. A churning beam of magenta and violet light shines up out of a hole in reality where the well once sat, sending blooms and streamers of strangely colored vapors and gas outward. Where this gas touches the serene garden surroundings, things flicker and shimmer as if they're not quite part of this reality.

The borders of this demiplane roughly coincide with the edge of the thick garden foliage that surrounds the area. A PC who peers beyond these borders sees thick but beautiful foliage, wildflowers, hanging sheets of moss, and vines as far as the eye can see. One square in from the central area is treated as difficult terrain, but beyond that, one encounters a solid, dome-shaped barrier that extends upward to a height of 200 feet—the foliage beyond and the sky above are nothing more than incredibly realistic illusions. Likewise, the dozen or so peacocks strutting through the area are not real and do not react to nearby fights at all.

Runelord Xanderghul's throne and the fourteen statues of him in this realm once had potent magical powers, but they're now all inert as a result of Xanderghul stripping some of that magic away to use in his plans and because of the destruction of his Runewell of Pride . This destroyed artifact lies at the opposite side, where the magenta and violet light and gas represent raw, unformed potential and unstable mythic magic. These ripples of magic and vapor are a danger to all intruders in this realm—see “Hazard” details.

Use the Eye of Arrogance scene for this encounter. Grant each PC 1 Mythic Point before combat begins for the legendary accomplishment of finding their way into the Eye of Arrogance.

Creatures: Xanderghul doesn't think there's anything of value left for his enemies in the Eye of Arrogance, but he's wrong—in his pride, he hasn't realized that those with mythic destinies can read echoes of his past thoughts here. Before the PCs can take advantage of that, though, they must contend with the guardians Xanderghul did leave behind. These guardians are posted here more as a symbolic gesture to protect the nostalgia of a demiplane Xanderghul has largely moved on from, yet that doesn't make them any less dangerous.

Of the ten larger statues in the area, the four closest to the throne are actually stone bulwarks that animate and stride forth to attack intruders. In addition, two risen runelords—Angothane and Thybidos (both once runelords of wrath)—stand vigil atop the dais at either side of the throne. Angothane addresses the PCs at the start of combat, mocking them with the following short monologue.

“Foolish pawns. You should have laid down and accepted your fates when our Lord Xanderghul cast his judgment on Sorshen and her pathetic, stolen city. You, who've dared to thwart his plans and who've stolen his valor and place in history, will perish in agony as he ascends to walk among the gods and takes his vengeance upon your pitiful, doomed world!”

Scene Notes Macro

@UUID[Macro.0oyhK8FbISMWSk9a]{Awaken Statues}

The Eye of Arrogance Severe 14

@UUID[Actor.kymDQRTMGzepi7ql]{Angothane} @UUID[Actor.EoLvvyE3u3OCUjTf]{Thybidos} @UUID[Actor.js01zek1NWXDmW4E]{Stone Bulwarks (4)} @UUID[Actor.ijidTNNt9tmXWaLD]{Shattered Runewell of Pride}

When combat begins, two of the stone bulwarks stay within 20 feet of each of these risen runelords so they can protect them with their statuary auras. They attack the PCs at range while the other two move to engage the PCs in melee. Angothane and Thybidos pelt the PCs with their devastating ranged magic and are quick to take advantage of any PC who's been affected by the ripples in reality caused by the shattered runewell (see Hazard). The risen runelords and constructs fight until destroyed.

Hazard: The Runewell of Pride was meant to obtain and store magical energy from prideful creatures and to link the Eye of Arrogance to Golarion, but when the Trinity Star destroyed the anima focus , the runewell bore the brunt of that devastation and shattered. It wasn't enough damage to destroy the demiplane, but it did transform the runewell into a hazard. A creature that falls into the five-foot-diameter hole where the runewell one stood can Grab an Edge with a @Check[reflex|dc:30|traits:manipulate,action:grab-an-edge|name:Grab an Edge] save; otherwise, they fall into the nothingness within and take @Damage[10d6[mental]] and @Damage[10d6[spirit]] damage each round (@Check[will|dc:33|basic] save, with a critical success indicating that the creature has willed itself back into the Eye of Arrogance and may reappear in the center of the demiplane). Apart from critically succeeding at this Will save, only magic that allows travel to other planes, such as interplanar teleport, can allow a fallen character to escape this fate.

Treasure: @UUID[Actor.DVUbJ5dYXEwG5aJQ]{Xanderghul's Throne}
A closer examination of Xanderghul's throne reveals a few “minor magical baubles” he left behind—treasures his followers scavenged from the ruins of Xin-Cyrusian and brought to him that he didn't feel were important enough to bring with him when he relocated to the Emerald Chambers. These items include a suit of +2 greater resilient standard-grade elven chain , a +2 greater striking greater vitalizing mace , a set of greater bands of force , and a leather satchel containing three greater potions of flying .

Concluding the Adventure.name: Concluding the Adventure
Concluding the Adventure.text:
Concluding the Adventure

Once the PCs defeat the guardians within the Eye of Arrogance and have destroyed or disabled the shattered runewell, no obvious route back to Xin-Shalast presents itself, but Xanderghul's throne begins to glow with a softly flickering iridescent light. At the same time, a faint urge to sit in the throne wells up in the PCs—this isn't enough to force them to do so, though. A PC who spends 10 minutes to Identify Magic on the throne and succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:32] or @Check[nature|dc:34], @Check[occultism|dc:34], or @Check[religion|dc:34] check determines that the magic of the throne is linked to the Throne of the Troll King, and that sitting upon it will allow a PC to observe that area far above but also allow them to teleport there. A critical success on the check also reveals to the PC that some of Xanderghul's memories are trapped in the throne as a sort of psychic residue that those who sit upon the throne can observe.

While the PCs can certainly use a spell like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.5bTt2CvYHPvaR7QQ]{Interplanar Teleport} to leave the Eye of Arrogance, those who sit upon the throne can exit with ease, reappearing anywhere within 50 feet of the illusory Throne of the Troll King on the surface above. Each time a PC does so, they experience one of the following memories. If you have fewer than 4 PCs, combine these memories so that the party experiences them all; if you have more than 4 PCs, some of the PCs experience duplicate memories.

  • Memories more akin to nightmares of being lost inside the heart of an immense eclipse and slowly being consumed before an immense warshard ripped him free and sent him hurtling through the Great Beyond to crash into Xin-Cyrusian. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[religion|dc:32|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge recognizes the eclipse as the same one that perpetually looms in the skies above the plane of Abaddon. These memories mingle with Xanderghul's nearly blinding rage and overwhelming need for revenge against the Saga Lands and all of Golarion in exchange for the torments and wrongs he's suffered—he blames Golarion's heroes for the fact that he hasn't already returned to rule the world again and intends to cause some sort of great devastation to earn his revenge.
  • Memories of the joy and relief of having a new body after possessing Aethusa, but also frustrations born of pride at not having his own body, and of plans to forge a new version of his more familiar flesh and bones to wear as soon as possible.
  • Memories of researching the methods of creating the risen runelords who serve him, as well as the decision to relocate to the Emerald Chambers to have better access to the “raw materials” needed to create more risen runelords. A PC who succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:32|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check or @Check[society|dc:34|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge knows that the Emerald Chambers are a Thassilonian complex used as a crypt for First King Xin and many of the runelords who followed. Only on a critical success does the PC know that the Emerald Chambers were located somewhere in central western Thassilon—not enough to go there, but enough to get a head start on researching the site. The memories end with Xanderghul leading his growing number of followers out of Xin-Cyrusian to relocate their base of operations to the Emerald Chambers.
  • More detailed information about the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.fr1AGcQo7WuvLvUi]{Raise Runelord} ritual. Share the basic details of the ritual with the PCs, but this information isn't enough for a PC to learn the ritual or even to research a version of the mythic ritual on their own, but if a PC succeeds at a @Check[arcana|dc:32|traits:concentrate,secret,skill,action:recall-knowledge|name:Recall Knowledge] check to Recall Knowledge, they realize that Xanderghul can use any risen runelord as a place to instantly return to life if he's slain.

If he remained behind, Kandirvek greets the PCs with a grin as they return to the top, reporting that the trolls seem to have largely given up on reclaiming the hilltop for now, and that he's seen “so many futures for you in the months to come—so many paths to take, so many directions we can go. There are some where you might rise greater than anyone ever before, and others where you perish without a whisper on your lips.” The dragon smiles again. “But I do not think that would be your fate, brave friends. Now, where to?”

Kandirvek is eager to carry the PCs wherever they wish to go next, and as they clamber onto his back he lifts off into the air, taking the PCs upwards until they leave the Troll King's Throne behind. It's easy to forget the horrors they've lived through and the terrible battle they know is ahead. As they fly away toward their destiny, their next adventure awaits in Pathfinder Adventure Path #220: Crypt of Runes.

Personification and Realm.text:
Personification and Realm

Though Nocticula's wings and three tails invoke memories of her form as a demon lord, her once vicious expression has become much gentler, and her shapeshifting ability is now used not to seduce or trick but to put others at ease. Nocticula enjoys interacting with others without inflicting the terror she once exuded, and many a desperate refugee or outcast artist in search of shelter has spoken of meeting a violet-haired woman on the road in the middle of the night who directed them to shelter, asking only to hear their story in payment for the kindness.

Nocticula reserves her ire for those who persecute artists or exiles. Whispered stories of the supernatural fates inflicted on those who harm refugees, betray the location of a safe house, or seek to censor or destroy a piece of art are sometimes spoken of by her faithful and admirers—not as tales to terrify or torment, but as stories to offer a sense of closure and justice to those who have endured or witnessed traumas and atrocities.

Nocticula resides in Midnight's Palette, an archipelago that lies in Elysium near its border with the Maelstrom. Its islands are places of striking beauty; each has a shape that echoes the artistic work of one of Nocticula's most faithful followers and features a different form of creative expression. On one, wisps of mist recreate the patterns of a dance. On others, compelling stories are uttered mysteriously near campfires, seashells create paths of haunting melodies, or figures from paintings come to glorious life. While these artistic havens are celebrations of creativity, they're also avenues for change. Nocticula believes there's a work of art for everyone that will make them reconsider the choices they've made. Encouraging conflicted souls to visit the Midnight's Palette has been crucial to helping her convince other demons and fiends to follow her path to redemption.

Nocticula travels between these islands freely but spends most of her time in the Halls of the Unforgotten, a hidden library filled with replicas of art censored or destroyed on countless mortal worlds. Few of these works are perfect copies; Nocticula's followers must recreate them as best they can before they manifest within the Halls, often working from memory or secondhand description after a piece is lost. Still, Nocticula cherishes these recreations as a record of creative work that would otherwise vanish from memory forever. She holds their location in the Halls of the Unforgotten as a closely guarded secret from any who might seek to damage them.

Aphorisms.name: Aphorisms
Aphorisms.text:
Aphorisms

“A shield cannot see.” Most of Nocticula's followers will eventually come across a work of art by another worshipper that they find distasteful or unwelcome. This phrase reminds the faithful that their dedication to defending the artistic work of another doesn't require them to like it, merely to protect it.

“Swallowed ink.” This phrase, which comes from the longer expression “better swallowed blood than swallowed ink,” captures the feeling of suppressing your own artistic vision to fit in or avoid backlash and is used in a variety of forms, from a curse (“I'd rather swallow ink”) to an encouragement (“Better than swallowed ink”).

“‘Til darkest dawn.” “Darkest dawn” is a common expression for midnight among many of Nocticula's followers, and this phrase can be used as a general substitute for goodbye, but it's most frequently a promise that better days are ahead. It encourages the listener to persevere until they reach a nearby sanctuary or other place of refuge.

Sacred Text.name: Sacred Text
Sacred Text.text:
Sacred Text

Nocticula's sacred text, Anew: The Art of Change, spread swiftly after her ascension. The original copy of the text is believed to have been written by Nocticula herself, and it's said that on these pages exist faint impressions of words from old debts, lip prints from love letters, and blood stains from kills accumulated during her existence as a demon lord. More commonly available copies of this text incorporate these elements as a reminder that to change is not to forget the past, but to find a new way to use it. Each volume of Anew: The Art of Change is different, with unique and bespoke illustrations on different pages. Upon first creation, many of these volumes leave swaths of blank space on the pages for new owners to add their own artwork.

Dogma and Worshipers.name: Dogma and Worshipers
Dogma and Worshipers.text:
Dogma and Worshipers

Nocticula teaches her followers that redemption is a form of change and that change is a work of art. Those who join her faith celebrate transformation in all its guises, whether found in Nocticula's ascension to divinity, in their own personal growth, or in the change from one day to the next. They believe that only by welcoming change, even when it's difficult, can one truly understand and embrace who they are—it's only by facing change that one realizes what about themselves is unshakable.

While she welcomes all forms of change and redemption, Nocticula takes special interest in transformations triggered by or expressed through art. She teaches that by experiencing art, you share in the artist's own journey of change and discovery in some small way, and that the right piece of art experienced at the right time can make a profound difference in the course of someone's life.

Nocticula's faithful know that not all share their affinity for art or change, and that fear of change can cause some to lash out. The Redeemer Queen's worshippers pledge to help those who find themselves at odds with their communities or those in power—the marginalized artists and outcasts who have been attacked, suppressed, or retaliated against for the change their art or existence represents.

Unsurprisingly, many of Nocticula's followers are artists themselves—particularly those whose work has been labeled heretical or scandalous, or who have had their creative endeavors destroyed or forbidden. For them, following Nocticula is a way to create community, protect those like them from harm, and commit to something greater than their own losses or pain. Yet even among those whose work is widely accepted or who face exile for reasons that have nothing to do with their creative pursuits, Nocticula's faith is popular; it attracts any who wish to exist in a world where artists have the freedom to create work that's true to their beliefs.

No matter what caused someone to seek refuge, Nocticula and her followers always welcome them, uphold their right to their beliefs, and defend them against any who might pursue them. This can manifest physically in the form of combat or magic, but it also extends to the defense of artists who are marginalized in less blatant ways, such as by having their work ignored, mocked, or purposefully misinterpreted. The only outcasts Nocticula or her worshippers turn away are those who take advantage of the assistance they're given in ways that harm others, or who pose a danger to the faith's sanctuaries or use the faith's permissive beliefs to perpetuate truly harmful ideologies and plots. For these, her faithful save their swiftest judgements and retaliations.

Temples and Shrines.name: Temples and Shrines
Temples and Shrines.text:
Temples and Shrines

Nocticula's places of worship, be they roadside shrines or sprawling cathedrals, are sanctuaries that provide refuge for anyone who has been cast out of their community or denounced for their art, whether they're followers of the Redeemer Queen or not. To protect those seeking safe harbor in regions where persecution is rampant, her temples are kept out of the public's view, often hidden by pieces of threshold art—an elegantly painted mural that hides a secret door to a small shrine beyond, for example, or an entrance beneath a mosaic-adorned archway that opens a magical portal only under the midnight sky. These works of art also serve a practical purpose­; they hide debilitating traps that can be activated by the sanctuary's priests and put Nocticula's experience as an assassin to good use against those who enter with ill intent.

In places where worship of Nocticula is more common, like New Thassilon, her temples are on full display as dedicated buildings, the most notable of which is Midnight's Gallery in Xin-Eurythnia. As a nod to the more clandestine temples found elsewhere, the entrances to Midnight's Gallery still incorporate threshold art, often integrating elements of illusion or transformation that are best appreciated at midnight—a mural that appears to move beneath starlight, for example, or an image of Nocticula in the shadows that can only be seen in darkness.

To reach exiles and artists who need the faith's protection, each temple maintains a beacon that guides those in need of refuge toward it. In most temples, this beacon is nonmagical and can be a wide range of things—it need not be a shining light. Some temples use beacons of scents maintained via incense burners along routes to the temple. Others incorporate clues in local artwork or recruit street performers who keep an eye out for the needy and convey directions via song or dance. In regions where suppression, censorship, and persecution are the norm, the faithful are more aggressive in both changing up their methods and helping those in need, constantly clashing against the enemy.

These clues and signposts are known as “notes” by Nocticula's followers (a word that disguises the sanctuary it represents). In addition to acting as subtle, creative components to guide those in need, notes can also be used as focal points of worship for travelers. They provide a sense of protection, as if whoever hears or sees them is safe within the walls of a physical place of worship. Sanctuary songs weave recognizable notes into popular traveling tunes and increasingly comprise most hymns and travel songs sung by the faithful.

Within a temple, Nocticula's teachings place few demands, asking only that temple doors remain open to all who enter with good intentions. Individual temples incorporate different forms of creative expression into their rites, and each place of worship is shaped by the artistic leanings of those who have passed through its doors. For many artists who have seen their work censured or censored, sanctuaries offer them their first opportunity to create freely. The artwork on display in these temples is as confrontational, unsettling, scandalous, or outright disturbing as it is beautiful and inspiring, with many displays managing to achieve all these elements. It is not an insult or a slippage of faith to create artworks that depict Nocticula's old traditions and past as a demon lord, but an expression of continued fervor—her followers must remain willing to challenge themselves and their beliefs, finding ways to live in the discomfort that can be caused by someone else's truth or art without decrying, destroying, or demonizing it.

A Priest's Role.name: A Priest's Role
A Priest's Role.text:
A Priest's Role

Many of Nocticula's priests practice their faith while traveling in search of those who need refuge. In addition to distributing sanctuary notes, sharing supplies, and looking for potential shrine locations, their most important task is to seek out artists whose work is in danger of being lost or destroyed and to bear witness to their artistry. Most carry extensive records of the art they've seen in their travels, bringing them back to be preserved within their home sanctuary's archives and making them available if needed to create copies of lost works. Those who can afford them make regular use of items like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.ngz7dYysC1NkBBRK]{Retrieval Belts}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.1pglC9PQx6yOgcKL]{Sleeves of Storage}, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.jaEEvuQ32GjAa8jy]{Spacious Pouches} to transport these works secretly and securely.

For priests tied to a specific temple, daily work is divided between those who train to defend the site and its residents, those who maintain the beacon, and those who push for the creation of new art by its members. Most members of a Nocticulan church go through each of these roles at some point, as temples embrace both the personal changes in a believer's life and the changing needs of the sanctuary itself. Nocticula's priests are each roughly active for a third of the day, ensuring there's always someone available to assist someone in need.

Temple defenders train to repel potential attacks and maintain the sanctuary's traps, but those are not their only duties. By involving themselves heavily in local politics and guilds, they remain informed about potential new threats to arts and artists. Priests who maintain the beacon are most active during transitional times of the day, including most mealtimes, and are responsible for making each church a haven. They resolve disputes, help new worshippers acclimate, and ensure those who leave have everything they need to succeed and spread the faith. While the steady stream of worshippers and outcasts makes most temples decentralized, the de facto leader of a site is often a member of this particular group.

The art-driven members of a church are most active at night in the hopes of gaining more direct inspiration from Nocticula. They push the sanctuary's artistic boundaries and encourage the faithful to express themselves in ways that challenge traditions and foster change. Often, they organize displays of artwork either in the sanctuary or amid the local community; they likewise gather and catalog the artwork collected by traveling priests and ensure the sanctuary doesn't become stagnant as it grows.

Adventuring priests of Nocticula don't usually tie themselves to specific temples but often find themselves acting as messengers and couriers between distant shrines. When a temple asks an adventuring priest to serve in such a way, they never push for expedience save in the direst situations. Temple-bound members know that an adventuring priest's free-wheeling lifestyle is a significant source of artistic inspiration.

Holidays.name: Holidays
Holidays.text:
Holidays

Nocticula's followers celebrate her rise to godhood on a holiday called First Midnight, which takes place at the end of the first day of the new year. First Midnights are upbeat community events that include art displays, performance festivals, and the distribution of new artistic work. Those who attend are encouraged to observe and enjoy the art over the course of the evening before choosing the piece that best resonates with them and using it as the basis for a silent prayer to Nocticula at midnight.

To celebrate and mark individual changes, the Redeemer Queen also encourages her followers to celebrate First Midnight on the midnight following any significant achievement or the completion of any major creative project. These personal First Midnights are intimate affairs marked by a meal with those who made the accomplishment possible. If the worshipper is on their own, they write a message to those they wish could join them for the meal and leave it in a place of natural beauty at midnight, where it's believed Nocticula finds it. It's said she then conveys its sentiments to those mentioned by the writer.

Relations with Other Religions.name: Relations with Other Religions
Relations with Other Religions.text:
Relations with Other Religions

Since her ascension to divinity, Nocticula has made an active effort to build alliances, eager to avoid the acrimony that plagued her life as a demon lord. In some cases, creating these relationships has been straightforward; Nocticula joined the @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.VG51y4FbTLdeGHZB]{The Path of the Heavens} pantheon soon after becoming a god, joining @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.JgqH3BhuEuA4Zyqs]{Desna}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.BNycwu3I21dTh4D9]{Sarenrae}, and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.aTYy1WHwAZiuei4h]{Tsukiyo} as a protector of travelers. While she's not actually associated with the act of redemption, her self-redemption has ensured that a strong bond of mutual respect has already formed between herself and Sarenrae, even though her focus on midnight puts her at the opposite end of things from an astronomical sense. Her membership in the pantheon has also helped her begin a tentative friendship with Desna, who shares her affinity for night and appreciation of beauty.

The friendship between Desna and Nocticula is still a burgeoning one, and the Redeemer Queen believes that Desna is too unmoored, with no real sense of purpose driving her followers' travels. Regardless, she has encouraged those who worship her to leave sanctuary notes on or near Desnan shrines during their travels and has welcomed Desnan priests into her sanctuaries.

While Nocticula's friendship with Desna is one of shared interest, the bond she shares with @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.0BH54ZVR8NcrGlMu]{Findeladlara} is closer to mutual admiration. The elven goddess' domain, Horizon Heart, is located near Nocticula's Midnight Palette, and the two greatly appreciate each other's taste in art. Findeladlaran and Nocticulan worshippers in New Thassilon have embarked on collaborative artistic projects due to this mutual respect, though this has also led to some conflict between Findeladlarans' belief in elven aesthetics as the highest principle of art and Nocticulans' desire for their art to have transformative effect.

Of all the deities associated with art, though, Nocticula's relationship with the goddess @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.gxwmzxUWBOhdgFSN]{Shelyn} is perhaps the strongest. Since Shelyn has already had eons to see the potential hidden within her brother, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.ZfN7jkK6boU1FuiS]{Zon-Kuthon}, it was no great leap for her to extend trust to the newly risen demon lord. Today, the two faiths often take part in art exchanges, where priests trade works of art with each other for display in the other faith's temples as a way to promote harmony and cooperation between the two religions.

Nocticula has had less success in her attempts to make inroads with @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.v67fHklTZ6LoU54q]{Cayden Cailean} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.eErEiVmBqltYXFJ6]{Iomedae}. Though she'd hoped that the two might warm to her given their common experience of having ascended to godhood, neither has been able to fully trust her because of her origins as a demon. Their fellow Ascended, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.GX6PF9ifR47Xyjg9]{Norgorber}, has been friendlier, but his association with assassins is too strong a reminder of her origins, and Nocticula generally steers clear of him. Otherwise, the Redeemer Queen has found some allyship with @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.AlL9GtlTldbqNoVm]{Calistria}. While some of the elven deity's teachings do remind Nocticula of her prior life, the two share a strong belief in freedom and respect for seduction as an art form, and despite Nocticula's belief in change, she accepts Calistria as she is.

Nocticula's most fraught relationship is with @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.aipkJQxP4GBsTaGq]{Lamashtu}. Though both ascended from demon lord to god, and though Lamashtu once predicted that Nocticula would be the next demon to follow in her footsteps, the Mother of Monsters was infuriated at Nocticula for turning her back on the Outer Rifts. Lamashtu believes that Nocticula is an opportunist willing to leverage her demonic origins in a quest for divinity and views her efforts to ingratiate herself with fellow gods as nothing more than a sign of weakness. Nocticula has a perhaps deeper insight into Lamashtu's hatred of her, for if Nocticula could rise from the Outer Rifts, why not any other demon?

Heroic Scion (Rare).name: Heroic Scion (Rare)
Heroic Scion (Rare).text:
Heroic Scion (Rare)

Regular people often quip about the eventful lives of legendary heroes with pithy witticisms such as “no good deed goes unpunished” or “no rest for the wicked.” Whatever the source of such wisdom, these words could correctly describe the never-ending struggle between good and evil and the fight for survival in a world of monsters and nefarious plots. For the most heroic adventurers, peril begets peril and one crisis often gives way to the next.

Choosing your Hero

The heroic scion gives a player the chance to play the reincarnated soul of a previous PC who has perished and moved on to the afterlife. The previous hero need not be mythic, nor even as high a level as the current PC, but the merging of their life into the form of the heroic scion catapults both into the higher stratum of mythic power.

Whether a player chooses a previous PC as their past life or selects another hero chosen from the world's history, the player gets to decide if their current character identifies as that past hero or simply recalls their previous adventures as they live their new life as a heroic scion. If the player has no prior PC to choose from, they can also select a dead heroic NPC ally or notable figure from a previous campaign. The player should work with the GM to determine who their past life was and then strive to flavor their mythic destiny feats so they echo their reincarnated soul more accurately from a narrative and flavor standpoint.

Such is the nature of growing in power. The pool of similarly powerful figures becomes smaller, and the stakes for future conflicts grow higher. For many such adventurers, it's difficult to find peace, especially if a past rival resurfaces. Such foes might demand a reckoning with the same heroes who defeated them before, and even if those heroes have gone on to the afterlife, they still may return to do battle with old foes once again.

These sons and daughters of destiny, known as heroic scions, return whenever trouble arises. Whether they return from the beyond as a reincarnated soul in a newborn body destined for glory or manifest within the soul of a hero who happens to be in the right place at the right time, the end result for the heroic scion is the same—the sudden recollection of astounding deeds and great victories from a past life. Academics debate whether these individuals share a similar soul born to fight against serious threats or whether every great power gives rise to a karmic enemy. Possibly the explanation is much simpler—great heroes come forward to battle great evil, and history remembers the champions of both sides.

A heroic scion's purpose goes beyond mere revenge or simple misadventure. These fated figures possess a true destiny: to defeat an enemy capable of altering the course of mortal life or the cyclical frustration of an enduring adversary. Should a scion, or even a party of scions, achieves total victory over their quarry, the universe tends to provide a new enemy worthy of their might.

Scions come from every possible type of adventurer but share preternatural toughness as a common trait. While they return to life from death within a new body, they're never exactly the same as their previous incarnation. Full details of their past lives are initially fleeting, but as the heroic scion grows in power, their old memories surface as their potency increases. Some might seek out old companions or their spiritual successors, while others soldier on alone, a unique thorn in the side of their equally timeless adversary.

Along with the heroic scion's perseverance, they exhibit other gifts. Most possess a strong sense of self and are all but incorruptible in that regard. They remember the lessons of history's great battles, having taken part in many themselves. Likewise, they recall their defeats and humiliations, yet they don't dwell upon these in a negative way—instead seeking to learn from past mistakes so that when they're faced with similar situations in this new incarnation, they can bring the wisdom of one who has suffered before to solve the problem. After so many years of conflict, heroic scions master familiar tactics and terrains and become experts in dealing with their recurring enemies. A heroic scion may rest when their nemesis is defeated but always remembers their place when the villain returns.

Eron of Jandelay.text:
Eron of Jandelay

Rarely seen, the erons of Jandelay serve an important function on their apocalyptic home plane. These spindly birdlike creatures tower over the landscape on seven thin legs, covered in ironlike feathers they can hurl with a flick of a wing. Scavengers and collectors, erons dispose of intrusive elements they discover on Jandelay, stashing them in nests for later assortment. Such detritus typically consist of dead adventurers and their gear; an eron won't hesitate to attack a living adventurer, though, and they make little distinction between living or dead “clutter” that doesn't belong.

Avenging Runelord (Rare).name: Avenging Runelord (Rare)
Avenging Runelord (Rare).text:
Avenging Runelord (Rare)

The absolute pursuit of personal power was almost universal among the runelords of ancient Thassilon. In their haste to stave off death, they created personal demiplanes, embraced undeath, fashioned powerful artifacts, and created foreboding strongholds in obscure branches of reality. Using all the magical might at their disposal, they sought to cement their legacies upon future generations, even after death. The spread of generational curses, the carving of visages into mountain peaks, the creation of faux faiths and secret societies that blurred the lines between cult and religion—all of these were pursued by the runelords in their goal of creating an eternal legacy.

Runelord Magic

The @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.journals.JournalEntry.vx5FGEG34AxI2dow.JournalEntryPage.09VwtSsYldMkVzU1]{Runelord} archetype appears on pages 114–119 of Lost Omens Rival Academies. While a PC doesn't need to be a wizard with this archetype to select the avenging runelord mythic destiny, it's certainly a thematically appropriate choice. Even if a PC isn't a wizard, though, various features in this destiny build off the school of Thassilonian rune magic and the seven sins, so having access to Lost Omens Rival Academies may significantly help when creating your avenging runelord. Note that if you do have the runelord archetype, you don't have to choose the same sin you chose for that archetype as you do for the avenging runelord destiny!

To most, the simplest route to a lasting legacy is through family. By passing on a name, trade, or beliefs to descendants, a person's influence may carry on long after they're gone. This, of course, wouldn't do for most runelords. To them, family was a weakness—one that either enemies could exploit or that could lead to betrayal from one's own blood. Runelords who did have children often endeavored to sequester their offspring's minds and bodies as repositories for their own souls, while those with no progeny of their own sought magical creations, influence over abductees, and other more twisted methods to prolong their existence.

A Previous Life

As an avenging runelord, a character isn't actually a reincarnated runelord (a PC seeking to play a reincarnated character should instead consider the @UUID[JournalEntry.pf2ap21905advent.JournalEntryPage.05heroicscionr00]{Heroic Scion} destiny). They remain their own person, yet their memories and dreams are influenced by the long-dead soul with whom their destiny has become entangled. They might claim to be the reincarnated runelord, or they might deny this influence or even not truly know whose soul has infected their own. When a PC chooses this mythic destiny, they should work with the GM to determine which of the dozens of previous runelords have infected them, choosing from those many runelords who have died and do not live on as undead to this very day. The GM can suggest a runelord whose legacy might be encountered at some point in this Adventure Path as a risen runelord or might leave the identity secret and encourage the player to lean into themes of envy, gluttony, greed, sloth, or wrath (noting that no runelord of lust or pride has yet died, and as such, cannot be used to create avenging runelords).

Such a mindset could only foster souls possessing an everlasting rage against death. And in the aftermath of several tumultuous events—particularly the recent awakenings of the runelords as well as the world-shaking Godsrain—many of these karmic seeds have begun to take root. The minds and souls of new runelords, along with the living descendants of ancient runelords, have been attacked by the souls of their grasping predecessors. Some of these scattered descendants and new adherents overcame the intrusions and lived their lives of their own, unaware of the supernatural doom hanging over their heads. For others, however, the supernatural incursions proved far more difficult to resist.

This was not a true reincarnation. The bitter souls of these long-dead wizards haven't been reborn into new bodies—the reward of a judged soul sent back to life.

Rather, those invaded by an avenging runelord's soul must constantly fight for control of their fate. Over time, they may experience flashbacks and déjà vu, uncovering the hidden identity within their bodies. As this influence grows, so to do bitter memories of rivalries with the Runelord Xanderghul or those like him.

Timewracked (Rare).name: Timewracked (Rare)
Timewracked (Rare).text:
Timewracked (Rare)

Those who travel outside the conventional flow of time are often regarded as powerful heroes or ambitious villains. A being with the force of will or cosmic purpose to change the past or travel to the future lives a life beyond the comprehension of all but the most significant of Golarion's formidable figures. Yet to meddle in the flow of time is to invite peril and danger far beyond what most are capable of enduring, and those who survive are sometimes known as timewracked.

The Most Dangerous Game

Few face greater danger than an adventurer who dares traverse the streams of time. There are many fell creatures native to strange dimensions and alternate realities, all of whom are sensitive to temporal manipulation. Like sharks sensing vibration in the water, such predators orient on those who wade into their oceans, hungry to consume both the temporal energy and corporeal forms of any foolish enough to disrupt time's linear flow.

Beyond that, time itself seems to generate hazards for those who attempt to break its rules. Obscure texts describe sudden storms, quakes, and deadly undercurrents with bizarre and unpredictable effects. Ancient cosmic myths mention bolts of lightning that transport those they strike to different times and places, even preventing a return to one's normal time.

For those traveling the contours of time, the road is often even more arduous than their peers believe. Perhaps due to an ancient curse or as the price of a selfless sacrifice, being trapped outside the normal flow of time comes with inconvenient and unpredictable consequences. For some, the ability to see the future or affect the past comes at the cost of influencing one's own time. For others, the danger of losing track of when you are can be as perilous as becoming lost in a dangerous realm. Even these predictable perils pale in comparison to becoming the object of those who hunt the timewracked. Bythos aeons, the hounds of Tindalos, siktemporas, and agents of the Ancient Ones themselves are all legendary predators of those whose actions might damage the flow of time—and they hunt the timewracked for even the tiniest infractions.

Those who travel outside of time might achieve the future they seek, but they can never know until they return to their own time. The very nature of their existence can cause their legacies to fluctuate. The great cyclops Urghan (tormented male cyclops primalist 17) is said to be trapped in a constant repetition of the decisions he made just before the Starstone fell, living in one reality for the most part but frequently responding to the stimuli of variant timelines, his ultimate goal being the protection of an empire from global devastation. Before then, several runelords created demiplanes or used advanced magic to lock themselves out of their own natural chronology, either to gain more time to prepare or one day return to a world that has already survived calamity.

Adventurers isolated from time see its flow in a variety of ways—but never in the same way as those who experience time traditionally. Their exposure grants them adaptive abilities that accelerate their movement or allow them to experience time at different speeds than others. With experience, they can channel their fluid perceptions, forcing a disadvantageous time flow onto their enemies. Ultimately, the ones who best adapt to their predicament learn to cheat mortality—not immune to death but not aging, either. Immunity to the rigors of time allows them to influence the events both before and after their native streams. There's no power quite like time travel, but also nothing more dangerous.

When Are You From?

The plot of the Return of the Runelords Adventure Path focused on Runelord Alaznist's abuse of the flow of time, accomplished with the aid of a mighty artifact now lost. Even given the assumption of her defeat, the damage done to the flow of time persisted—most blatantly in the sudden return of the time-locked city of Xin-Edasseril to the modern era. While not all of those who have spent the past 10,000 years locked within that city have mythic destinies, a PC who hails from this part of New Thassilon has a perfect backstory for this mythic destiny. If a player wishes to play a character who is native to this part of the world, keep in mind that they were likely born eons ago, before Earthfall. It'd be a significant roleplaying challenge to play a character fresh out of their temporal element, but since several years have passed between Xin-Edasseril's return to the flow of time and the start of this Adventure Path, you should assume that any PCs who hail from this land have spent those years becoming acclimated to the new world they find themselves in.

An even more outlandish genesis for a timewracked PC is that their existence in this timeline may not be stable—they might not even be from this campaign's timeline, having slipped across parallel realities into this campaign as a side effect of Alaznist's temporal tampering's during Return of the Runelords. One could even imagine a character from the Starfinder setting being hurled back in time after a disaster involving a black hole or other temporal distortion. In all such cases, the player should work with the GM to make sure their character still fits into the current campaign's storyline and isn't such a fish out of water (or out of time) that the entire adventure must take a back seat to their character's slow acclimation to this new reality.

Warshard Warrior (Rare).name: Warshard Warrior (Rare)
Warshard Warrior (Rare).text:
Warshard Warrior (Rare)

From the earliest days of civilization, many heroes became associated with their legendary weapons. These brave adventurers, who faced many mythic challenges in their time, eventually moved on to the afterlife, for such is the way of mortality. While their mortal remains were consumed by cremation, interment, or the natural process of decay, the magical weapons they left behind suffered no such deterioration. These artifacts and relics would often later be taken up by new heroes, and thus the cycle would repeat.

How Did You Become a Warshard Warrior?

When a PC chooses the warshard warrior destiny, they must decide how they encountered the warshard in question. In the Revenge of the Runelords Adventure Path, the Godsrain is still a relatively recent event, and so it could be that a PC was struck by a tiny fragment as it fell during the event, or perhaps they were infused after touching a fallen shard they discovered. The nature and flavor of this infusion don't need to have any bearing on the character's subsequent feat choices as they gain levels nor on the type of weapon they choose to bond with.

In time, as the Godsrain is separated from the present by generations, it's possible for a hero in the future to become a warshard warrior much in the same way a sorcerer gains their magical power—through a supernatural legacy handed down from ancestors—but for the purposes of this campaign, a PC should have a more direct link to the original warshard. They might even wear the fragment as a token or have it embedded harmlessly but impressively in their flesh.

When shards of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.deities.Item.88vRw2ZVPax4hhga]{Gorum}'s body rained down upon the world during the Godsrain, this cycle transformed. Known today as warshards, the divine remnants of Gorum's physical form quickly became highly sought-after treasures wherever they fell. As one might expect from fragments shed from the body of war god, these shards became invaluable components for the forging of new weapons or the bolstering of existing ones.

But what of those rare cases where a warshard, however small, strikes the body of a hero? What of those rare cases where a physical embodiment of the dead god of war becomes absorbed into the soul of a mortal? In these astonishing instances, a new type of hero can arise, one who doesn't shed their mortal shell in death but instead continues their legacy in the form of the weapon they wielded.

These so-called warshard warriors bear or once bore a piece of the divine metal that fell during the Godsrain. It might have been shaped into crude-looking armor or carried as a makeshift shield, or it might simply adorn that hero's clothing. It could even have pierced their flesh and left its influence behind, transforming into an unremarkable fragment of slag. Regardless of the manner of infusion, these warshards impart both fortitude and purpose to the affected warriors. For most, the shard unifies both the wielder and weapon, elevating the pairing when the tide of battle rises. For others, the shard enables an even more perfect union, blending the essence of both until they become one, the weapon forever holding the spirit of the warshard warrior.

Destiny Definitions

This destiny revolves around a concept that is summarized below.

  • Warshard Weapon: This is a specific weapon you have chosen to infuse your destiny into during your daily preparations. Most warshard warrior feats work best when coupled with a warshard weapon. You can only have one warshard weapon at a time. A warshard weapon gains the mythic trait.

Among those few who combined with their weapons to become one unique intelligent item, the soul of Yrrelin (malicious male serpentfolk lich 21) now resides within his scythe Villainy. He now seeks to behead Golarion's greatest heroes, one after another, in a zealous push to “bring all life closer to the headless god, Ydersius.” Those who hold the blade are overcome by the wickedness of its former master and aren't in control of their own actions.

For good or ill, the skybound slaughter of Gorum threw the world into a new age of heroes, villains, and mythic artifacts. Most warriors who received the war god's blessing knew right away the spark of partnership between them and the weapon that was once merely regarded as a tool of their trade. The more time spent wielding the weapon, the greater its magical abilities and the greater the warrior's understanding of its singular nature. In the end, few can say how powerful the bond between a weapon and its warshard warrior will grow.

Risen Runelord

Risen Runelord Gear

A risen runelord's polearm is an extension of their being and cannot exist without them, vanishing upon their death. This doesn't prevent a risen runelord from claiming, carrying, or using other items, and most higher-level risen runelords keep real magic items that remain behind after their death.

Risen runelords are created by a powerful ritual invented by Runelord Xanderghul—a ritual called @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.fr1AGcQo7WuvLvUi]{Raise Runelord}. All risen runelords are at least level 11 creatures. Once created, a risen runelord has no capacity to become more powerful, as they are manifestations of their legacy at a specific point in time (although given enough time and resources, a risen runelord could potentially find a way to overcome this limitation on self-improvement).

A risen runelord has a modicum of free will, but as long as the one who created them via raise runelord lives, they're bound to their creator's desires. A risen runelord ordered to undertake obviously self-destructive actions might, at the GM's discretion, resist the command and could potentially even break free of their creator's control.

Since raise runelord draws upon a runelord's legacy as it exists within the Dreamlands, no risen runelord can ever sleep or dream. Xanderghul can use a risen runelord in a special way: he can use any risen runelord (including ones he didn't create) as a spare body. If he's slain, his soul can instantly jump to the closest risen runelord to replace them and continue the fight, unless the PCs can disable this defense during the second adventure in Revenge of the Runelords. Regardless of level, all risen runelords are mythic creatures and are immune to sleep effects.
